On April 15th, a mob attacked a land vendor outside of the court in Nakawa (Kampala), amidst a land dispute involving the vendor. Police intervened and escorted the woman to safety. [size=small]

actor1: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Internal Security Organisation
notes: During the month of April, a dissident and former convict was reportedly tortured at a Police ISO safehouse in Kyengara (Wakiso district) for a period of 72 days before escaping. The victim noted the presence of dozens of detainees, and alleged widespread torture in the various safehouses he was detained in.

On April 15th, a mob beat two men to death in Kabwase village in Kibanda sub-county (Rakai district, coordinates for Kibanda used at precision 2). The source suggests the reason for the attack was due to the men allegedly stealing a motorbike, but the source also suggests the deaths may be related to a personal fued, which has been made to look like vigilante activity. Police are investigating the incident. [size=small]

On April 13th, police attempted to disrupt an FDC rally in Jinja (Jinja district), and arrest Dr Kizza Besigye. FDC supporters engaged in clashes with the police, who fired tear gas and live rounds in response. Of the confirmed injuries, a one year-old child was injured by a stone being thrown, whilst a pregnant lady collapsesd after inhaling tear gas. Soldiers later intervened. [size=no report]

On April 13th, a mob killed a man who had murdered his wife and child (one fatlity coded). The incident took place in Kyakachwende village in Katatemwa parish (coordinates for Katatemwa, Kakumiro district, used at precision 2). [size=no report]

On April 12th, a mob attempted to attack a police vehicle, after its driver had accidentally run over and killed a young child. Soldiers intervened, and reportedly fired live ammunition to disperse the mob. The event took place in Dokolo town (Dokolo district). [size=no report]

On April 10th, Rwandan soldiers crossed the border into Uganda, and detained three farmers at Nyinarushengye village (Kabale district, coordinates for Katuna used at precision 2). The farmers (who were accused of being plain clothes Ugandan soldiers were taken across the border to Byumba in Rwanda and were briefly detained, before being released.

In a two week period beginning approx March 29th and ending April 12th, seven people were killed by lynch mobs in Jinja. There are no specific details for the individual cases, though it appears that six of the incidents happened within the same week, implied to be at the start of the time period (seven events coded at time precision 2, with six in the first week). [size=no report]

On or before April 9th, students from Nakyenyi secondary school (Lwengo district) protested against the lack of clean drinking water at the school, after three days of shortages. The headteacher fled the school; police have been deployed to prevent damage to school property. [size=no report]
On April 8th, traders demonstrated at Nalule Arcade in Kampala, following a considerable rent increase. Police intervened, and made a number of arrests. [size=no report]

On or before April 7th, clashes broke out between police and mechanics in Garage Street in Kabale (Kabale district), seemingly as police came to clear them from the road for rehabilitation (they have used the area for repairs). Police used sticks, while the mechanics threw scrap metal and stones at the police, injuring one police officer. [size=no report]

assoc_actor_1: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Military Police
notes: On May 4th,  police and UPDF soldiers (alongside other, unspecified, security agencies) evicted around 300 members of the Bunyoro Kitara Reparations Agency group from the land they had been occupying for several years in Hoima town (Hoima district). Authorities arrested two people for resisting eviction. The stated reasons for the eviction were that the premises were not designed for the rituals the group had been performing, and that they were 'tarnishing the image of the kingdom'.

On May 4th, demonstrators gathered in Gulu town (Gulu district), after police had abandoned a body outside Gulu hospital the previous day, demanding that the body be properly buried. The demonstrators threatened a local health official as well as police; police then intervened, with the source indicating that they buried the body. [size=no report]

On April 3rd, a mob attacked an 18 year-old student, who was accused of stealing a bed sheet from a house in Oryang Ojuma Cell (coordinates for Oryang A Parish, Kitgum district, used at precision 2). Two people were arrested, although the source suggests that several others were involved in the attack. [size=small]

In a two week period beginning approx March 29th and ending April 12th, seven people were killed by lynch mobs in Jinja. There are no specific details for the individual cases, though it appears that six of the incidents happened within the same week, implied to be at the start of the time period (seven events coded at time precision 2, with six in the first week). [size=no report]

On April 3rd, riot police and soldiers fired tear gas and water cannons at merchants protesting their eviction from several commercial buildings in Kampala. The traders say that they have already paid their rent to the deceased owner of the buildings they operate in, and that the new owners have been harassing them to pay this rent. [size=no report]

Around April 3rd, a mob attempted to lynch five people in Abim (Abim district), reportedly in relation to a cattle raid. The victims are recovering in hospital, although there is no further information about the specific groups involved. [size=no report]

In a two week period beginning approx March 29th and ending April 12th, seven people were killed by lynch mobs in Jinja. There are no specific details for the individual cases, though it appears that six of the incidents happened within the same week, implied to be at the start of the time period (seven events coded at time precision 2, with six in the first week). [size=no report]

In a two week period beginning approx March 29th and ending April 12th, seven people were killed by lynch mobs in Jinja. There are no specific details for the individual cases, though it appears that six of the incidents happened within the same week, implied to be at the start of the time period (seven events coded at time precision 2, with six in the first week). [size=no report]

On April 1st, students from Ngabo Academy attacked students of the Mbarara Institute for Social Development in Ruti (Mbarara district), wounding eight, and damaging property belonging to the institute. There is no clear motive for the incident at this time, and police have arrested 12 suspects so far. [size=20]

In a two week period beginning approx March 29th and ending April 12th, seven people were killed by lynch mobs in Jinja. There are no specific details for the individual cases, though it appears that six of the incidents happened within the same week, implied to be at the start of the time period (seven events coded at time precision 2, with six in the first week). [size=no report]

actor1: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
notes: On March 30th, three Local Defence Unit soldiers attacked and killed three pastoralists (one of whom was a ten year-old boy) at Otumpili village (coordinates for Alerek sub-county used at precision 2). The three LDU soldiers have been arrested, and 33 ammunition cartridges have been found at the scene of the incident.

In a two week period beginning approx March 29th and ending April 12th, seven people were killed by lynch mobs in Jinja. There are no specific details for the individual cases, though it appears that six of the incidents happened within the same week, implied to be at the start of the time period (seven events coded at time precision 2, with six in the first week). [size=no report]

In a two week period beginning approx March 29th and ending April 12th, seven people were killed by lynch mobs in Jinja. There are no specific details for the individual cases, though it appears that six of the incidents happened within the same week, implied to be at the start of the time period (seven events coded at time precision 2, with six in the first week). [size=no report]

On or before March 29th, residents of Kirundo and Nyamwishenya sub-counties protested in Kisoro District Council (Kisoro district), storming the building to demand the creation of a new constituency for their areas. The protesters accused local politicians of failing to do so, despite assurances from President Museveni that a new constituency may be established. Police dispersed the demonstrators, removing them from the building. [size=no report]

On March 28th, students rioted at Kuambogo University in Kampala, following an attempt by University administration to prevent students from being able to complete an academic year if they did not pay fees within 12 weeks of term beginning. Windows of university buildings were smashed (as were the windows of several vehicles); police fired live ammunition and tear gas at the students to disperse them. One student lost a hand when he attempted to throw a tear gas canister back at police. [size=no report]

assoc_actor_2: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Special Forces Command; Taxi Drivers (Uganda)
notes: On March 26th, taxi drivers blocked roads at various locations in Entebbe (Wakiso district), in protest at attempts by authorities to introduce loading fees. There were reports of taxi drivers beating colleagues who did not participate in the strike action. Police and Special Forces Command used tear gas to disperse the demonstrators, and made 19 arrests. [size=no report]
On March 26th, a lynch mob killed two suspected motorbike thieves, in the Amber court area of Jinja municipality (coordinates for Jinja used). [size=no report]

On March 26th, residents of disputed land in Kyegonza sub-county (Gomba district, coordinates used at precision 2 due to a lack of precise information on the location) killed at least three men at the disputed land, who were suspected of being employed by one of the disputants (a Kampala-based lawyer). The group were reported to have injured others (though details are unclear), and killed animals on the property belonging to the lawyer, and destroyed his property.
On March 25th, a mob stoned a man to death in Kotido town (Kotido district), after the man had stabbed and wounded another man in a street fight [size=no report]

On March 25th, police rescued a man from a lynch mob in Lira town (Lira district), who accused the man of being a thief. A mob then went to the police station and apprehended the alleged thief, and murdered him. Police fired weapons to disperse the mob; a bullet hit and wounded a nearby civilian (who was seemingly not involved in the vigilante action), who is recovering in hospital. [size=no report]

source: Chimp Reports; Daily Monitor (Uganda); Weekly Observer
notes: On March 24th, police shhot dead a man who was suspected of attempting to assassinate junior ICT minister Idah Nantaba and her bodyguard at Ggavu village in Kasawo sub-county (Mukono, coordinates for Kasawo used at precision 2), while another fled. Subsequent reports indicate the two men were unarmed and were merely civilians. Three police officers have reportedly been arrested in connection with the killing.
On March 21st, a suspected thief was attacked by a mob in Lira, after he allegedly stole a handbag. The mob beat him to death, and set the body alight. [size= no report].
On March 22nd, taxi drivers protested the reinstatement of fees by authorities in Entebbe (Wakiso). Police dispersed the demonstrators with tear gas, and made three arrests. [size=no report]

actor1: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Internal Security Organisation
notes: On March 20th or 21st, a police officer attached to Kabulengwa police station was detained by ISO agents - on suspicion of supplying arms to gangs - and taken to an unknown ISO location, where he was likely killed whilst in detention (coordinates for Kabulengwa, Wakiso district, used at precision 2). His body was dropped off at a morgue in Kampala on the 21st, and is said to have shown signs of torture (actor 1 coded as Police ISO, and actor 2 as civilians with police as assoc actor).

On March 19th, a lynch mob killed two and wounded two others at Sugur swamp (coordinates for Wera, Amuria district, used at precision 2). The attack was likely in relation to a murder that had taken place a few days before. [size= no report].

On March 18th, two police officers shot and wounded two civilians close to the Ywande trading centre on the outskirts of Luwero town (coordinates used), in an unprovoked attack, and outside of the area the police were supposed to be guarding. The ownership of the land is contested. Authorities are investigating the attack.

On March 16th, an armed group (suspected of coming from South Sudan, and coded as an UCM from that country) attacked a kraal in Narengepak parish (Kaabong county), killing two, and stealing 40 head of cattle.

On March 15th, police clashed with an armed gang in Nyakaizi cell at the outskirts of Mbarara (coordinates for Kakoba Division used). One gang member was killed in the clash, and three were arrested. The gang had been active in the area, and the clash came as part of a police crackdown.

actor1: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Uganda Wildlife Authority
notes: On March 15th, Wildlife Authority officers clashed with poachers in Bwambara subcounty (Rukungiri district, coordinates for Rwensama used at precision 2). One officer was shot in the exchange of gunfire, and died en route to the hospital. One suspect have been arrested.

actor1: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Uganda Wildlife Authority
notes: At an unspecified time in March, a militia suspected by Amuru district officials of being Wildlife Authority soldiers disguised as Madi militiamen (and coded as such) torched 48 dwellings in Acholiber village in the disputed Apaa locality (coordinates for Apaa, Adjumani district, used at precision 2 in the absence of geographic information on the village). A number of people were reported to have been displaced by the actions of the group.

On March 14th, students rioted at Kigezi High School (Kabale district), over a dispute surrounding participation in a football tournament, amidst financial problems at the school. Students reportedly attacked a teacher, and threw stones at riot police. Police used tear gas and live ammunition against the students, though no injuries are reported in the source.[size=no report]

On March 14th, a group of men (coded as UCM) attacked a family residence in Kohompo village in Bufujo sub-county (no geographical information found, coordinates for Kyenjojo used at precision 3), killing five children and injuring their mother. The group were said to be looking for the father of the family.

actor1: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Military Police
notes: On March 14th, a lecturer at Makerere University was assaulted by three Military Police on the campus, who knocked him unconcscious with batons. The Military Police had earlier dispersed students who had gathered at the University.
On March 13th, a police officer was alleged to have raped a female suspect in custody in Kyenzige (Kagadi district). The officer has been arrested.

On March 13th, protesters from Rupa village potested in the District HQ at Moroto (Moroto district), over unpaid compensation following the sale of their land to a mining company. A local politician has disputed their claims, saying those who were owed money have been paid. [size=100]

On March 12th, residents of Lugonjo (a suburb of Entebbe) knocked down a wall built by a local businessman, which had encroached on a road used by the inhabitants of the area. The mob alleged that the businessman had links with the police. [size=no report]

On or after March 10th, a suspected thief was attacked by a mob in Lira, after he was allegedly in the process of stealing a motorbike. The mob beat him to death, and set the body alight. [size= no report].

assoc_actor_1: Refugees/IDPs (Democratic Republic of Congo); Hema Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On 10 March 2019, refugees (presumed to be Congolese refugees of the Hema ethnic group) rioted at an unspecified refugee camp in Kyegegwa district (presumed to be Kyaka 2 camp; coordinates for central settlement of Sweswe used at GP2) after documentation went missing. A security guard employed by an international NGO was wounded in the event, after a refugee attacked him with a razor blade. [size=no report]

On March 10th, South Sudanese students studying at Nkumba University (Luamtundwe, Wakiso district) protested at the death of a colleague on the highway close to the University. They were subsequently joined by other students from the University, and prevented traffic from moving on the road. Police dispersed the protesters.

On March 6th, a small protest took place in Kampala, by a group of people concerned at the apparent disapearnece of a street vendor arrested by police on February 12th. Police arrested four of the protesters, and denied that they are still detaining the previously arrested man. [size=several]

On 4 March 2019, men armed with knives attempted to attack staff from an international NGO in Kyegegwa (Kyegegwa district), after a woman became agitated when the NGO staff attempted to instruct her on safely washing her child. The staff fled, whilst the security guard for the NGO was stabbed and wounded by the attackers.

On March 4th, students burnt down parts of a school at an unspecified location in Koro sub-district (Omoro district), in protest at the removal of three staff members, and inadequate rations. Seven students were subsequently arrested.

On March 2nd, a police officer fired at the road, apparently to scare a man he had arrested (note that circumstances surrounding the arrest are not clearly specified). The bullet ricocheted, wounding two students who were passing by at the time. Police are investigating the incident, which took place in Wandi (Arua district).

On March 2nd, a mob of several dozen youth attempted to beat FDC politician Dr Kizza Besigye as he left a TV station in Mengo (Kampala). FDC accused the mob of being from Bobi Wine's People Power movement; Bobi Wine himself has suggested that the youth were in the pay of the government. Besigye escaped unhurt. [size=dozens]

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On March 1st, gunmen (described as 'militiamen' in the source, coded as UAG) from the DRC abducted a fisherman from Kyehoro landing site in Kabwoya sub-county (Hoima district), and took him to the DRC. The group threatened to shoot pursuing fishermen.

On or before Feb 27th, boda boda (motorcycle taxi) drivers stormed the courthouse at Bugiri town (Bugiri county), to demand that a merchant they accused of defrauding them faces justice, and refunds them money. [size=dozens]

On or before Feb 27th, youth stormed municipal offices in Kitgum (Kitgum district), in protest at the non-payment of youth livelihood stipends. Authorities have acknowledged the problem. [size=no report]

On Feb 26th, two security guards (assumed armed) were attacked and killed by an unknown group at a school in Kyengera (Wakiso), using bladed weapons. One person has been arrested in connection with the attack.

On Feb 26th, police fired live ammunition at a group which had moved in to occupy contested land at a college in Kapisa parish (Butaleja district). The group (coded as rioters) had destroyed a tractor on the land when they entered it. [size=no report]

assoc_actor_2: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-); Journalists (Uganda); Women (Uganda)
notes: On Feb 24th, two soldiers - acting in their capacity as bodyguards for retired Major General Matayo Kyaligonza (the current Ugandan ambassador to Burundi)- were filmed assaulting a traffic police officer (recorded as a civilian, with police as assoc actor2) after she had summoned the vehicle over a traffic offence. The incident - which has sparked national outrage, took place in Seeta (Mukono). A journalist filiming the incident also alleged that the soldiers assaulted him. The two soldiers have been arrested, and the retired Major General called in for questioning over his alleged involvement in the assault.

On Feb 23rd, residents of Iriiri sub-county (Napak district, coordinates used) burned logs at an unspecified location along the Moroto-Soroti road, in a protest against administrative boundary changes. Police and demonstrators were reported to have clashed, causing an unspecified number of injuries, and six demonstrators were arrested.

On or around Feb 21st, Ugandan truck drivers staged a protest in Elegu (Amuru district) at the Uganda-South Sudan border, following the killing of a colleague in Rumbek on Feb 20th, and refused to enter South Sudan given insecurity. The drivers demanded his body be repatriated, which appears to have happened on Feb 23rd.

On Feb 20th, police dispersed Democratic Party protesters who had stormed the Central Police station at Jinja, using tear gas. When protesters reassembled and attempted to march through the town, police once again dispersed the protesters through 'caning' them. A local journalist covering events was also injured.
On Feb 18th, parents stormed a school in Jinja to protest the poor quality of the school buildings. Police arrived at the scene, but do not appear to have intervened in the protest.

On Feb 14th, a lynch mob set fire to a taxi carrying three individuals who were suspected of stealing cattle, in Kawomya village (Mukono district, coordinates for Mukono used). One man was killed in the attack, the other two survived, and are in police custody.

On Feb 14th, demonstrators (including taxi and boda boda drivers) blocked the Hoima-Fort Portal road at Hoima (Hoima district) using logs and rocks, in protest against continued dust in the area resulting from road works. Police and soldiers dispersed the protesters (seemingly with gunfire), and arrested 30.

On Feb 13th, a police and military task force clashed with a village militia in Kpele village (Hoima district, coordinates for Kigorobya used), as part of a hunt for illegal immigrants in the area. State forces fired at the militia, prompting the residents to kill one police officer with arrows (before dismembering him) and wounding another. 43 people were arrested in connection with the incident.

On Feb 13th, police and UPDF soldiers forcibly removed a number of families (implied to be over 500) from several villages in Kyabisagazi parish (Hoima district). The families were locked in a dispute with a Hoima-based businessman over ownership of the land. During the 3am raid, four young children (all under the age of 2) were killed in fires which been started to clear the land of the settlements.

On Feb 12th or 13th, police and soldiers fired shots into a bar in Kisoro (Kisoro district) in order to disperse patrons who were refusing to leave. Stray bullets killed a nearby civilian. One police officer has been arrested, and a soldier is on the run.

On Feb 9th, a woman was raped at Kirinya Police Station (at Kira, Wakiso district) by a police officer whilst she had been taken by her partner and accused of infedelity. The officer has been charged with rape.

On Feb 8th, residents of Buhanika sub-county (who had been recently evicted as part of a land dispute) went to the residence of the MP for Bugahya (coordinates for Buhanika sub-county, Hoima, used at precision 2), and are now camping in his compound. The residents say that are left without the means of survival now they have been forcibly evicted.

On Feb 7th, a militia from Kween district (armed with machetes and bows) attacked a government delegation from the Ministry of Lands and Local Government, as part of a boundary dispute. The event occurred at River Atari (coordinates for Bunambutye, Bulambuli district, used). The source does not specify how many were injured, nor the extent of their injuries.

On February 6th, boda boda and taxi drivers, together with members of the business community, blocked the Hoima-Fort Portal road using rocks, bricks and logs (coordinates for Hoima, Hoima district, used at precision 2). The protesters accused the Chinese company responsible for building the road of not taking sufficient action to prevent large amounts of dust from affecting residents of the area.

On Feb 6th, a group armed with basic hand weapons and suspected of belonging to the Acholi group attacked Madi civilians in the Zoka area (Adjumani district), as part of the bitter Apaa land dispute. Four Madi civilians were wounded, and 13 huts were torched.

On Feb 6th, police and military forces prevented a demonstration from taking place at Makerere University. The demonstrators were objecting to the lack of lectures at the University (as part of the ongoing strike), and misleading statements from the University's management on the matter. A number of students were arrested, and some students burnt wood on the roads in the area. There are no further details at this time.
On Feb 5th, a mob lynched to death a suspected thief in Nyakabungo village near Muhanga (Rukiga district, coordinates used). An accomplice escaped the mob. Police are investigating the incident.

On February 4th, 15 men who were presumed to be court ballifs, backed by police, forcibly evicted over 100 families in Rwensambya village (coordinates for Buhanika, Hoima, used), burning 50 dwellings. The evictions occurred following a court ruling on a land dispute (actor 1 coded as Government of Uganda, with police as assoc actor)

On Feb 4th, five local MPs mobilised demonstrators in Gulu town (Gulu district), to protest the failure of the government to resolve violence associated with the Apaa land dispute. Police intervened immediately, and arrested the politicians in addition to a number of activists and youth.

On Feb 3rd, a police officer shot and wounded two boda boda drivers as they (along with others) attempted to storm the police station at Kasingo (Hoima). The mob had been trying to reclaim their motorbikes, which had been impounded during an earlier street brawl which the police had dispersed.

assoc_actor_2: NRM: National Resistance Movement; Police Forces of Uganda (1986-)
notes: On February 2nd, NRM youth from Jinja clashed with an NRM Mobilising team, after the team organised a meeting without the youth's knowledge. Police intervened to protect the leader of the Moibilising team. There is no indication that weapons were used.

On or before January 31st, a group of men assaulted and killed two people in Katabi (Wakiso). The wife of one of the victims claims that the attackers were a group of welders, who were involved in a dispute with her late husband, though this has not been confirmed.

On or before January 28th, police prevented a march from protesters to the State House in Entebbe, arresting five. The protesters were attempting to stop their eviction from Namiiro wetlands (close to Entebbe Airport, Wakiso, coordinates used).

On January 28th, a gang broke into the GIZ compound in Iriaga (Gulu). They beat two security guards (assumed armed), before looting the compound, and causing damage to several vehicles parked inside the compound.
On January 25th, police used tear gas and live rounds against cannabis users in Kabale town, arresting five. There were no reports of injuries.

assoc_actor_1: Labour Group (Uganda); Police Forces of Uganda (1986-); Military Forces of Uganda (1986-)
assoc_actor_2: Labour Group (Uganda); Police Forces of Uganda (1986-); Military Forces of Uganda (1986-)
notes: On or before January 25th, two groups of boda boda (motorcycle taxi) operators clashed with clubs and stones at the Busega taxi stand on the outskirts of Kampala. Police and UPDF intervened to separate the groups, in a dispute which related to certain boda boda operators being relocated as part of road works.

On January 23rd, five people (at least four of whom were Acholi) were attacked and wounded by a Madi militia using basic hand weapons, in the village of Goro B in the disputed area of Apaa. 14 huts were also looted and then torched by the militia. Displacement has been mounting in the area as a result of the unrest.

On January 22nd, residents of Orom and Akurumo sub-counties in Kitgum protested against the arrival of pastoralists from Karamoja (location unclear; coordinates for Orom, Kitgum district, used). The protesters allege that the herders damage local ecosystems, and accuse the Karamojong of being behind thefts.

On January 22nd, demonstrators gathered on the Gulu-Kampala highway in or around Koro (Omoro district), following a series of traffic accidents that have resulted in several deaths. The protesters temporarily blocked the road with stones.

On January 19th, a mob armed with machetes beat and cut a police officer who had attempted to arrest a man for defilement, leaving him injured. The event happened in Dingo village in Nawanjofu sub-county (Butaleja, coordinates for Namatala used).

On January 19th, a mob hacked to death a former UPDF soldier in Atapar (coordinates for Aligoi, Bukedea, used). The man - who was involved in a local dispute over land allocation - threw what the mob believed was a grenade into a crowd during the demarcation proceedings. The device did not explode, though a mob chased and killed the man.

On January 19th, a mob attacked a UYD official in Kasaka parish (coordinates for Kirumba, Kyotera district, used). The UYD official had stolen the microphone from a Minister who was speaking at the event. There are conflicting accounts regarding the conduct of the Minister's bodyguards (recorded as soldiers), with one witness claiming they were beating the official. A bodyguard fired his gun into the air to disperse the mob.

On January 18th, men armed with spears and bows (believed to be from the Madi ethnic group) attacked the village of Juka B in Apaa parish, as part of a bitter land dispute. They abducted ten people, burnt food, and torched 48 houses
On January 18th, the mayor of Lira punched and pushed against a wall a journalist from Unity FM radio at the Municipal Council Chambers of the town. Police intervened to protect the journalist.
On January 18th, police and gang members clashed in Jinja. The gang members opened fire on the police, who shot dead all three gangsters.

On 17th or 18th January, five UPDF solldiers were suspected of killing and dismembering a civilian in Haibale village (Kabarole district), after an altercation in a bar involving one of the soldiers. The suspects have been arrested.

On January 16th, around 200 protesters demonstrated in Sumbwe village (Mukono, coordinates for Mpunge used), following the non-payment of compensation for property lost as a result of the construction of a new water treatment plant.
On January 15th, a lynch mob killed an elderly man in Bunashimolo (Sironko, coordinates for Mafudu used) suspected of practicing witchcraft. The circumstances described by the source are convoluted.

At an unspecified time in the month of January, street children rioted in Jinja (Jinja district), following the killing of one of their own in a failed robbery. The rioters attacked civilians with stones and hand weapons, though it is unclear how many were injured. [size=no report]
During the month of January, a cattle keeper was killed by suspected Jie raiders at Auu Kirute (Agago district, coordinates for Adilang used at prec2).
On January 11th, police arrested a man in Mbale in connection with a robbery. The man died whilst in police custody. Three officers have been arrested in connection with the death.

On January 10th, around 1,000 protesters from Bugonga village descended upon the office of the deputy Regional District Commissioner in Entebbe (Wakiso district), to protest against their contraversial eviction.

assoc_actor_1: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Internal Security Organisation
notes: On or before January 10th, police arrested two alleged ADF operatives in Kampala. The suspects are now in ISO custody. Police also claimed to have intercepted six explosive devices carried by ADF operatives over the Christmas holiday period.

On January 10th, over 200 evicted residents of Akokoro sub-county of the disputed Maruzi ranch area (Apac district) rioted against other residents who had accepted money to relocate. Police and soldiers intervened and fired teargas and live bullets to disperse them. FIve arrested.
On January 9th, a drunken UPDF soldier gunshot wounded a colleague and two civilians in Kyamukerege village in Nyabukara ward (Kabarole district). The soldier has been arrested.

On January 8th, unknown gunmen shot dead the chairperson of the Peace Committee for Panyangara sub-county in Loletyo parish (coordinates for Panyangara, Kotido district, used). The source speculates the victim may have been killed for his uncompromising stance on cattle theft in the area.

On January 7th, residents of Kikooza village protested against a power outage that had affected a number of villages in the area for two days (coordinates for Nabuti (one of the affected villages), Mukono district, used). The demonstrators blocked the roads by lighting fires; police dispersed the demonstrators.

On January 6th, a husband seriously beat his wife, prompting residents of Ruhija (Kanungu district) to intervene. The man killed one of the residents with a hoe (the chairman of the village), and injured two others with a panga. A mob formed and beat the attacker, before police intervened and took the man to hospital.

actor1: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Uganda Wildlife Authority
notes: On January 3rd, Uganda Wildlife Authority forces were reported to have destroyed 48 huts in the disputed area of Apaa between Adjumani and Amuru (the specific location is Wadi-Kampala, Palyech parish, Lakang sub-county, Amuru district). Given the absence of coordinates for the area, Apaa in Adjumani has been used at precision 2). Injuries to the residents have been reported, though the source of the injuries is not explicitly stated in the source.

On January 3rd, a group armed with machetes and sticks and riding a motor boat attacked two fisherman in the waters adjacent to Nsonga-A LC 1 in the new Kikuube District (note that there is currently no detailed information on these locations and boundaries. Accordingly, Lake Albert has been coded at precision 3). One fisherman was killed, and the other jumped into the lake and swam for the shore. The attackers also stole fish the fishermen had caught.

On and before December 28th, Ugandan police and armed forces were reported to have been amassing at the border with the DRC at Mpondwe (Kasese), in response to the flow of refugees coming from the DRC.

On December 28th, a mob killed two suspected thieves in Kiyana village. The suspects had been accused of stealing cattle; during the confrontation, the suspects threw bricks into the mob, injuring two teenagers, before the crowd killed them, using stones.

On December 27th, a mob killed two suspected motorbike thieves at an unspecified location in Luwero district (the source notes one of the attackers came from Koko village; accordingly coordinates for this location have been used at precision 2).

On or before December 27th, South Sudanese gunmen (allegedly belonging the SSPDF) were accused on raping two women (one of whom was a 15 year-old girl) near Ngomoromo (Kitgum). The incident comes amidst incursions by South Sudanese forces into disputed border areas.
On December 26th or 27th, police dispersed protesters demonstrating in support of Bobi Wine (who was prevented from performing a concert by the police on Dec 26th) in the Kamwokya suburb of Kampala.

On December 26th, a lynch mob attempted to kill a suspected theif in Fort Portal (Kabarole). A nearby security guard intervened, firing two bullets into the crowd, wounding a student. The security guard has been arrested.

On December 26th, police arrested several suspectes of an earlier clash in the area of Kyangwali (Hoima) over a dispute regarding the resettlement of refugees (clash recorded in a separate event). They beat/tortured them.

On December 26th, two groups clashed in the area of Kyangwali (Hoima), over a dispute regarding the resettlement of refugees. Following the event, police arrested several suspects, and were reported to have beaten/tortured them (recorded as a separate event).
On December 26th, an elderly Rwandan refugee was shot and killed by unknown gunmen at Nakivale Refugee Camp.

On December 25th, Turkana raiders shot and killed a motorcycle taxi driver on a road in Kamio sub-county (Kaabong district), for unclear reasons. Earlier that day, the raiders had undertaken what the source describes as a 'botched' raid.

On or before December 25th, fishermen protested at Rock Landing site in Jinja municipality in Jinja against the failure of police to arrest a trades group who they allege is responsible for murdering their colleagues.

assoc_actor_2: Aid Workers (Uganda); Military Forces of Uganda (1986-)
notes: On December 23rd, refugees rioted at the Bidi Bidi camp (Yumbe) over problems with the supply of food. INGO property was smashed and a number of staff members assaulted (coded as Aid Workers). UPDF were deployed to the camp following the disturbances.
On December 22nd or 23rd, unknown gunmen killed a man in Kalapata, for unclear reasons. The source suggests the attackers were looking for a Local Defecnce Unit informer.

actor1: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Fisheries Protection Unit
notes: On December 21st, soldiers from the Fisheries Protection Unit shot and wounded a fisherman at Bosa landing site (coordinates for Bufumira, Kalangala, used). The victim had been accused of catching immature fish, and was alleged to have been running from the soldiers when he was shot.

On December 21st, four youths in their mid-twenties assaulted an off-duty senior CID officer in Kasese. The attackers beat him, and also used a knife to wound him in the head. The source states that the motivation behind the attack was theft; UPDF soldiers have arrested four suspects.
On December 20th, a suspected thief stabbed two brothers as he robbed their home in Kasese. After an alarm was raised, a lynch mob formed, and stoned the suspect to death, crushing his head.
On December 19th, residents of Katabi (Wakiso) protested at Garuga police station, against a police round-up of fisherman earlier that day, accusing police of engaging in arbitrary arrests.

On December 15th, police entered Jinja town to prevent a concert by Bobi Wine MP, arresting several (unspecified) members of his team. Bobi Wine (who is currently in hiding, as of 16th Dec) and his lawyer accused police of beating several of his supporters.
On December 14th, a doctor was killed by unknown gunmen as he returned home to his wife (who is a magistrate), in Iganga. The target and motive behind the attack is unclear.

On and before December 13th, authorities in Nwoya district engaged in a recruitment drive to assemble a vigilante force numbering around 700 (with approx 100 youth drawn from each sub-county of the area), to combat the charcoal trade. A local official noted obstruction from political and business elites, as well as police, who are implied to be involved in the trade.
On December 12th, an armed gang on motorbikes robbed a businessman of 30 million shillings at Bukomero (Kiboga), and then shot and wounded a civilian as they fled.

On December 12th, police intercepted an armed gang on motorbikes at Bukomero (Kiboga), killing two of the gang members, and recovering two motorbikes they had stolen. This was the same gang that had robbed a businessman at the same location (see separate event).
On or around December 11th, taxi drivers demonstrated in Rukungiri, over the company awarded a tender.

On December 11th, a UPDF soldier killed four members of his family in Okut village (coordinate for Aloi sub-county, Lira, used), before fleeing the area. He was later arrested by military intelligence.

actor1: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Uganda Wildlife Authority
notes: On December 9th, a park ranger shot dead a man gathering firewood at an unspecified location in Mt Engon national park (coordinates for Bumbo, Namisindwa, based on villge of victim, used at precision 2). Circumsances are unclear. A similar incident occurred a month prior. The ranger was detained.
On or around December 8th, two gunmen riding a motorcycle shot a shopkeeper in Dokolo (Lira district), and fled the scene without stealing from her shop.

On December 8th, unknown gunmen shot dead a businessman on the outskirts of Rukungiri (and close to the border with Buhunga sub-county; coordinates for Rakungiri used). The attackers allowed a passenger and the driver of the motorcycle taxi he was riding to escape.
On December 6th, police and military forces conducted a security operation in and around Arua town, making over 100 arrests of suspected criminal elements in the area.

On or before December 6th, a lynch mob comprising boda boda (motorcycle) taxi drivers chased down a motorcycle chief, attacking the thief with sticks and stones, before pouring petrol upon the victim and setting him alight. The event occurred in Butasabwa (coordinates for Semuto (Nakaseke) used.

At some time between December 3rd and 5th, protesters from Rukondwa entered the offices of the district council speaker for Masindi. The demonstrators were aggreived at the lack of quality roads serving their parish, which had limited their access to essential services, and compelled them to sell their goods to middlemen at a reduced price.

On December 4th, protesters from Kahengye village entered the offices of the Resident District Commission at Rukungiri, demanding compensation for delayed compensation payments for damages to property and crops which resulted from a government and World Bank-backed water project.

On December 3rd, unknown gunmen shot a businessman four times outside his home in Mayuge town. The victim survived the attack, and is said to be in a serious but stable condition in hospital. The attackers fled the scene on their motorbike.

assoc_actor_2: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-); Labour Group (Uganda)
notes: On December 3rd, unknown gunmen killed a motorcycle taxi driver and his passenger (a Lance Corporal with the UPDF - assumed unarmed) at an unspecified location (coded as Kamion sub-county, Kaabong district). The wife of the soldier (who was travelling with him) survived.
On December 2nd, unknown gunmen shot dead a mobile phone trader on the outskirts of Arua town. They then fled the scene, without stealing anything.

On December 1st, an armed group shot and wounded a security guard in Arua. The source indicates that the attackers had intended to steal from the bar he was guarding. The victim is recovering in hospital.

During the two weeks prior to December 1st, at least three instances of assault by security personnel deployed against civilians in Mutungo parish (Kampala) were reported to have taken place, according to the zonal defence secretary for the area. Coded as three events spaced across two weeks at time precision 2; the source describes the state forces as 'Night Patrol Forces', and have been recorded here as Police.

On November 30th, a gang stabbed a boda boda (motorcycle taxi) driver to death in Bweyogerere (Wakiso), and stole his motorbike. The gang have been behind a spate of robberies in the area. Three suspected members have since been arrested.

On November 30th, demonstrators gathered at the High Court in Fort Portal (Kabarole) to protest unpaid compensation by the Ugandan National Roads Authority, for the destruction of property and acquisition of land during the construction of a road nine years ago. The source says that over 600 residents were affected by the road, but does not specify how many attended the protest.

On November 29th, police attempted to arrest a man suspected of committing sexual assault in Madi-Opei (Kitgum). The suspect fled, prompting police to open fire, killing the suspect's mother in what is described in the source as an accidental killing.

On November 29th, protesters stormed the police post at Madi-Opei (Kitgum), following an incident earlier in the day where a mother of a suspect had been shot by police. The police had already vacated the station, anticipating a demonstration.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On November 28th, an armed group (or groups) suspected to be Congolese militia attacked fishermen and their property at various sites in Buseruka, Kabwoya and Kyangwali sub-counties. Details are unclear, including the number of injured.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On November 28th, an armed group (or groups) suspected to be Congolese militia attacked fishermen and their property at various sites in Buseruka, Kabwoya and Kyangwali sub-counties. Details are unclear, including the number of injured.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On November 28th, an armed group (or groups) suspected to be Congolese militia attacked fishermen and their property at various sites in Buseruka, Kabwoya and Kyangwali sub-counties. Details are unclear, including the number of injured.

On November 27th, a lynch mob of around 100 people gathered at Atiak police station (Gulu) to lynch a truck driver who had hit and killed a child earlier that day. Police used tear gas and live ammunition to disperse the mob, wounding a mother and her child with gunshots in the process.

On November 27th, the Premier of Buganda - Charles Peter Mayiga - embarked on a visit to Masaka under heavy security, in a trip which had been delayed due to disputes over protocol. Protesters were reported to have taken place at or near Masaka by Kooki royalists, who were angered by the visit of the Premier. According to the source, the road was blocked by the demonstrators.

On November 27th, suspected police seriously injured a civilian, though this is denied by the authorities. The event took place in Mutungo parish (Kampala). The victim is in hospital, and is reportedly unable to walk or sit upright.

On November 26th, FDC supporters gathered in Rukungiri town to commemorate the killing of a party member the previous year, in an event which did not receive permission from the authorities. Police dispersed the demonstrators with bullets and tear gas after forcing their way into the FDC party offices; the source indicates that at least some FDC supporters fought back. Over 50 FDC members were arrested, including some prominent members. Subsequently, a ban of FDC rallies in the Ankole sub-region was declared by the Police Inspector General.
During the week beginning November 26th, UPDF soldiers arrested over 200 individuals connected to the charcoal trade in Atiak sub-county (Gulu), and confiscated significant quantities of charcoal.

During the two weeks prior to December 1st, at least three instances of assault by security personnel deployed against civilians in Mutungo parish (Kampala) were reported to have taken place, according to the zonal defence secretary for the area. Coded as three events spaced across two weeks at time precision 2; the source describes the state forces as 'Night Patrol Forces', and have been recorded here as Police.

On November 23rd, the chairperson of the Veterans Association of Rwenzori Kateebwa was reportedly attacked at his home in Nyango in Bukuuku sub-county, Kabarole. The individual had been accused of corruption at a meeting in October. Note the source does not specify the manner in which he was attacked, nor the severity of the attack. Between one and three armed men are described as being behind the attack.

During the two weeks prior to December 1st, at least three instances of assault by security personnel deployed against civilians in Mutungo parish (Kampala) were reported to have taken place, according to the zonal defence secretary for the area. Coded as three events spaced across two weeks at time precision 2; the source describes the state forces as 'Night Patrol Forces', and have been recorded here as Police.

On or before November 19th, protesters gathered in Ayur-Alali (Kitgum, coordinates for Kal sub-county used) to protest the process surrounding the establishment of a sugar cane farm in the area, and alleged abuses by Ugandan security forces guarding the site.

assoc_actor_1: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
notes: On or before November 19th, UPDF units deployed to unspecified locations along the Congolese border, and recruited Local Defense Units to secure several villages along the border. The deployment is linked to recent ADF activity in the DRC.

On November 19th, protesters - including politicians and businesspeople - gathered in Gulu town (Gulu district) following repeated power blackouts in the town and its environs. The protest was dispersed by police and UPDF soldiers, who fired tear gas and possibly live ammunition at the protesters. At least one person was injured, and at least three were arrested.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On November 17th, a militia group from the DRC (wearing Congolose army uniforms) attacked Ugandan fishermen with guns near Kaiso (Hoima), killing at least seven. The fishermen were looking for the body of another fisherman who had been dismembered in an attack earlier that same week.

On November 17th, riots broke out in Alito (Apac), following the murder of a child, allegedly by two Indian nationals. Events have not been clearly established in reporting, though at present it appears as though clashes between rioters and police broke out at the funeral for the murdered child, with at least two civilians being shot and wounded (one report suggests three). One report states that roads were barricaded, either at Alito or Lira town (see separate event on the same day).

On November 17th, riots broke out in Lira town (Central), in events seemingly linked to riots in Alito (see separate event). Police (and UPDF reinforcements) used tear gas and live ammunition to disperse the rioters, injuring five. Conflicting reports suggest that Indian nationals were targetted in the violence. Several journalists from a local radio station were arrested by police for allegedly inciting the riots.

actor1: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Internal Security Organisation
notes: On November 16th, a controversial South Sudanese business elite - Lawrence Lual Malong - went missing in Kampala. It was later learnt that he was picked up by UPDF soldiers working on behalf of the Police Internal Security Organisation (ISO). He was released from ISO custody on the week beginning 31st Dec 2018. He was being investigated on numerous allegations, which mainly involved illicit financial activity and fraud. Malong does not appear to have been charged with any offence, though is still a person of interest.

On November 16th, a mob formed in the village of Enzeva (coordinates for Arivu, Arua used), after a coach reportedly hit a pedestrian. The group severely beat the conductor of the coach, though the driver and another member of staff escaped. The mob then set the bus on fire (the source is unclear as to whether the passengers were still on the bus at the time, though it reports that no passengers were injured).

On November 16th, workers from the water board at a location in Lyantonde stormed the headquarters of the board, to protest delays in the payment of their salaries, and against poor working conditions.

On November 14th, police fired bullets and tear gas at youth in Kawempe (Kampala), to break apart an allegedly unauthorised meeting regarding missing money which had been promised by the government to the youth. According to the source, police 'violently arrested' a number of youth, but the police vehicle carrying the arrested crashed, and the arrested were released with the help of other youth. The source does not indicate that the youth were behaving violently.

actor2: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Uganda Wildlife Authority
notes: On November 14th, a mob chased and threw stones at a member of the Wildlife Authority at Bufuma (Bududa), after he was alleged to have been having an affair with the wife of one of Bufuma's residents. The officer shot at the crowd that was converging on him, killing one and wounding another, before fleeing. The mob then lynched another member of the Wildlife Authority in retaliation. Five people have been arrested in connection with the case, though the officer responsible for shooting into the crowd is reported to be on the run from authorities.

actor1: Unidentified Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On November 12th, a militia group from the DRC attacked Ugandan fishermen near Kaiso (Hoima). The source suggests the victims were shot with arrows, before being dismembered and dumped into the water. Five fishermen were killed, and two seriously wounded
On November 12th, a lynch mob killed a suspected hitman in Hoima town. The hitman had wounded two civilians with a machete, one of whom alerted neighbours.

On November 11th, an unidentified group (coded here as a communal militia) set fire to a school in Rakai, and locked the doors from the outside to prevent students from escaping. Nine students died in the blaze (one reports says 10 died), and at least 37 were injured. Six people have been arrested in connection (reportedly including staff and students of the school), though no motive has been established.

On November 10th, a vigilante mob chased a police officer who had shot a suspect in an assault case (coded as a separate event). The officer killed one member of the mob, before escaping. The mob then burnt property belonging to the person who had made the initial assault accusation. The officer has been arrested.

On November 10th, a police officer killed a suspect who was in the process of being arrested in an assault case. The suspect reportedly attempted to steal the officer's firearm - the officer then shot the man, prompting a vigalante mob to form (see separate event). The event took place in Tajar village (Bukedea).

On November 10th, police arrested 80 people on minor charges such as pickpocketing or drug offences after they participated in a concert by Bobi Wine MP (the alias of Robert Kyagulanyi) in Busabala (Wakiso).

On or before November 9th, newly arrived refugees from South Sudan protested against inadquate food at the Omugo refugee camp (Arua), and proceeded to take a number of humanitarian aid workers hostage, as well as a police officer, who was disarmed by the crowd. They later released the hostages and returned the weapon. Nine suspects have been arrested.

On November 9th, two Muslim groups clashed in Arua town (one faction was named as the Kibuli faction), prompting police intervention. During the clashes, two police officers were injured. It is unclear whether there were injuries on the side of the clashing groups.

On November 8th, an unknown gunman shot and killed a prominent local businessman in Kasojo Trading Centre (Kagadi). The victim had previously run for local political office. Update: four people have been arrested in connection with the murder.

On November 7th, demonstrators waiting for the outcome of a church theft case outside the Magistrates Court in Kayungainsulted and attempted to hit the Minister for ICT, Idah Nantaba. They were prevented from doing so by one of her assistants. The case is enmeshed in a bitter local political dispute.
On November 7th it was announced that Ugandan police had arrested over 300 suspected criminals, as part of a crackdown in Kampala.

On or before November 6th, soldiers from the South Sudanese army (SSPDF, formerly SPLA) who crossed the border into Uganda at Ngomoromo during August, were reported to have raped two women (in addition to molesting women in the area, and stealing from the local population). The soldiers are reported to be from Division 7 of the Cobra Battalion, and are commanded by Lt. Colonel Ruben Mayom Chol.

On November 5th, 80 members of the Police Flying Squad were removed from service, allegedly because they did not make it through a new screening process. The elite squad is currently being overhauled, and replaced with a new Organised Crime unit.

On November 5th, a police officer shot dead one man and wounded another over land in Kitarasa village (Kabarole). The source describes the victims as trying to attack the police officer with a spear and machete.
On November 2nd, police dispersed rioting students at the Uganda Christian University in Mbale, using tear gas and live rounds. The riots broke out following a disputed student election.

On November 1st, police prevented a meeting of supporters of Bobi Wine's People Power movement at the Idudi trading estate (Iganga), which was convened to settle a dispute between two politicians claiming support from Bobi Wine. Supporters of one politician - Mercy Walukamba - threw stones at the police in protest at the decision to prevent the meeting from going ahead.
On November 1st, an unidentified group attacked and beheaded a man in Mbale, allegedly stealing the decapitated head after the murder.

On November 1st, residents of Kitigoma, Buikwe district (coordinates for Buikwe used) formed a lynch mob to kill an alleged murderer, who had turned himself in to the police. The mob stormed the police station at Kitigoma, and blocked the main road for an hour. Police used tear gas and live bullets to disperse the rioters.

On November 1st, a local businessman was killed and his wife injured by a gang wielding machetes. The event took place in Semuto (Nakaseke), and - according to the source - followed threatening letters being distributed in the surrounding area by gangs.
During the week beginning October 29th, youth leaders in Bukomansimbi gathered to protest the arrest of around 20 youths, who had defaulted paying loans (coordinates for Bukomansimbi Town used).

On October 31st, the UPDF announced that it was retiring 17 senior military officers, including the Coordinator of Intelligence Services - General David Sejusa - who has been in an acrimonious relationship with the authorities for many years.

On October 30th, high school students rioted at Kigezi High School (Kabale), with younger students reported to be attacking older students, in disputed circumstances. Police used live ammunition and tear gas to disperse the students.
On or before October 30th, approximately 100 teachers stormed an administrative office in Kitgum, to protest the non-payment of their salaries since July.
On October 28th, a soldier killed a local resident in unclear circumstances.
On October 28th, a mob formed to attack a UPDF soldier in Matuga (Wakiso), after he killed a local resident earlier that day. The soldier was rescued by police.

On October 27th, a reverand from Kween district mobilised villagers to recover his stolen cattle, leading to a clash (weapons unspecified) in the remote area of Kapsakek (coordinates for Bunyiny, Kapchorwa, used). The village militia fled, though the reverend was decapitated by the cattle rustlers. Three suspects have been arrested, though six remain at large.

On October 26th, 63 politicians from the FDC party - all from the Ankole region - publicly resigned from the FDC, and joined the new party of the former FDC leader (General Mugisha Muntu), known as the New Formation (founded in September).

On October 23rd, drivers associated with the company Taxify protested at the Taxify office in Kampala. The dispute relates to a system used to calculate passenger discounts and driver bonuses, which has resulted in a number of drivers being unable to access their accounts, as the company has accused them of fradulent activity.

On October 22nd, youth NRM supporters demonstrated in Lira over an apparent corruption case in the town. Police used teargas, and engaged in 'running battles' with the youth, dispersing the protest. 10 of the youth were arrested.

On October 22nd, students protested at Kyambogo University (Kampala) over a decision by University management to increase a range of fees. Police used rubber bullets and tear gas to disperse the students.

On October 21st, a riot broke out at a football match between two educational institutes, which was dispersed by police, who used tear gas and gunfire against the rioters (note that the source does not mention any casualties or fatalities). Two students were arrested by the riot police.
On October 21st, a lynch mob killed three suspected motorbike thieves in Hoima, setting fire to the corpse of one of the victims. Police are looking for those involved in the lynching.

actor1: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: On or before October 19th, a group of SPLM-IO soldiers from South Sudan carried out several instances of violence against civilians in Koboko district (Arua), including raping an unspecified number of women; raiding cattle; and firing their weapons at civilians.

actor1: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: On or before October 19th, UPDF soldiers engaged with South Sudanese SPLM-IO soldiers which had been abusing and attacking civilians in Koboko district (Arua). One SPLM-IO soldier was killed in the firefight, and another arrested. Several others were reported to have fled.

On October 18th, five junior UPDF soldiers (wearing civilian clothes) were filmed seriously beating and abducting an opposition MP, Yusuf Kawooya in Kampala. The video sparked widespread outrage. On 20th October, the UPDF announced that it had arrested the men, who would be courtmartialed.

On October 17th, a gang armed with machetes attacked and wounded two civilians in Kabano B village (coordinates for Kyotera district used). The attack took place in the victims house, though nothing was stolen by the attackers.

actor1: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
notes: Between 25th September and October 17t, the UPDF recruited 6,626 individuals into the proposed Local Defense Units, purportedly established to help combat crime and assasinations.
On October 16th, residents of Hoima town burned tires in protest against the failure of local authorities to clean the area. The demonstration was resolved at the intervention of a local official.

On October 15th, FDC President Patrick Amuriat Oboi was reportedly arrested by police in Bunyangabu district (Kasese), following a dispute between police who were attempting to prevent the politician from travelling to Kasese town, saying that he did not have a permit to hold a rally. It appears he was released later that day.

On or before October 15th, students from a local technical college stormed the Hoima district headquarters in protest at the substandard facilities and inadequate teaching, calling for the Principal to be removed.

On or before October 13th, around 2,000 market traders gathered in Jinja to protest their eviction from a UPDF-owned site in Mpumudde (Kimaka Division). An official at Kimaka Division claimed that the local authorities agreed a Memorandum of Understanding with the military dating back to 2001 for continued use of the site by the traders, which a UPDF spokesperson denied.

On October 12th, residents of Kambuye village (Mybende) clashed with 'agents' of an individual named George Kaweesi, who claims to own land in the area. The Kambuye village militia - using spears and bows - killed one of the agents sent by the land claimant, and attempted to kill three other residents of the village, before stealing goods and money. 16 members of the village militia - including two local councillors - have been arrested in connection with the violence.
On or before October 12th, police used tear gas, canes, and bullets to disperse residents of Lusanja village (Wakiso) who resisted eviction from their homes.
On October 11th, members of the disabled community of Kabale protested in Kabale town, drawing attention to the increasingly dilapated conditions of the rehabilitation centre of the town.

On October 11th, Francis Zaake MP (who had been arrested and tortured along with Bobi Wine MP) returned to Uganda after spending 40 days in India, where he had been receiving medical treatment for the alleged torture. The MP was picked up by security agents when his plane landed at Entebbe, and taken by police to his home, allegedly to prevent demonstrations of support from the public.

During the first half of October, demonstrators set fire to a vehicle at Bendegere (Wakiso district), as part of a land dispute which saw a number of residents being forcibly evicted. Police arrested 28 people in connection with the demonstration.

On or before October 9th, councillors from Luwero county were attacked by a mob at an unspecified location within Luwero county. The incident occurred in the context of a land dispute between rival Indian and Pakistani business interests. The attackers were armed with machetes, although the source only mentions that the councillors were pelted with stones by the mob.

On October 9th, police attempted to disperse a crowd in Soroti, who were celebrating Independence Day. The police said the crowd had become violent, and two police officers fired into the crowd, hitting a fifteen year-old bystander. The officers have been arrested pending an investigation into the incident.

On October 8th, police clashed with demonstrators at Kiryatete (Hoima), who had blockaded the main road in protest at the deteriorating condition of the road. Police said the protesters had become violent, prompting them to deploy teargas and live bullets. Three organisers of the protests were later arrested.

On or before October 7th, protesters from Ruhjia sub-county- led by a local MP - stormed the district headquarters of Rubanda county (Kabale). The demonstrators were opposed to decision to build a secondary school in a neighbouring sub-county, which was difficult for residents of Ruhjia to safely access due to the geographical remoteness of the area.

On October 6th, riots erupted in Nawangisa village in Bugweri county (Namutum) over the decision to relocate a health centre to a different parish. One demonstrator was killed by police gunfire. The police said it had been forced to fire after the protesters threw stones at the police, wounding 16.

On 4 October 2018, an explosive device detonated and wounded a child at Kisugu (Kampala), taking off his left hand. The family of the victim claims that the device was left over from a recent UPDF deployment in the area, although this is not confirmed.

On October 2nd, dozens of youth gathered at an unspecified location in Ibanda district (coordinates for Ibanda Town used) to protest what they deemed to be a misallocation of 50 million shillings donated by President Museveni to youth in the town.

On September 29th, two police inspectors were abducted by unknown armed men at Entebbe Airport. The two had attempted to block military intelligence officers from arresting a constable with the counter-terrorism unit (see event dated 24th September, also in Entebbe). The two inspectors were then seized by the unknown men, who were driving in a civilian vehicle, and have not been seen since.

actor1: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Joint Anti-terrorism Task Force
notes: On September 28th, Joint Anti-terrorism Task Force arrested nine members of a suspected terror cell (coded as UAG) in Lubaga (Kampala), shooting one in the process, who died of his injuries shortly afterwards (no report of resistance or clash during the incident).
On September 25th, refugees from the region gathered outside the headquarters of the UNHCR in Kampala, to protest against insecurity they have been facing in refugee camps.

End September (likely), a counter-terrorism police constable alleged that he was abducted by suspected military intelligence officers after posting anti-government comments on social media, and tortured at a facility at an unspecified location. Location unclear. He escaped.

actor1: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Uganda Wildlife Authority
notes: 23 September 2018: Four poachers were shot dead and a fifth injured by Ugandan park rangers in Queen Elizebeth park, located near Rubirizi town in Uganda.

On September 22nd, the UPDF anounced that it would begin recruiting 'Local Defence Units' in Kampala, Mukono and Wakiso districts from Sep 25th to Oct 1st, ostensibly in response to a series of assasinations of high-profile individuals in recent months. Prior to this, President Museveni had announced that a purge of 'criminal and corrupt' elements of the police would begin, whilst special forces units would provide protection for elite politicians, businessman and military officials.

On September 21st, a Ugandan and Rwandan who were accused of robbery were attacked by a neighbourhood lynch mob in Kisoro, before police intervened to rescue the two. A third suspected robber fled the scene.

On September 20th, soldiers beat protesters who had gathered to support the return of Bobi Wine MP in Kasangati (Wakiso) with long sticks, leaving two injured on the head. Similar incidents were reported to have occurred at an unspecified location(s) on Entebbe Road.

On September 20th, Bobi Wine MP (the alias of Robert Kyagulanyi) returned to Uganda after three weeks in the United States, where he had been receiving medical treatment following his detention and alleged torture by the Ugandan security services. Police escorted the MP to his home. A heavy police presence was reported in Kampala, and demonstrations were banned. Authorities arrested a number of journalists and civil society members shortly before his return. Ten days later, the treason charges made against Bobi Wine MP and his 34 co-accused were deferred until December 3rd to give time to gather evidence.
On September 18th, residents of Kibiito (Bunyangabu district) demonstrated against the poor quality of the roads in their area, digging trenches across the road. [size=no report]
On September 18th, a lynch mob beat and then burnt alive a suspected motorcycle thief in Nauyo (Mbale district, coordinates for Bukasakya Parish used at precision 2). [size=small]

On September 12th, police and students once again clashed at Makerere University (Kampala). Police fired live ammunition as well as tear gas at the students, though no injuries were reported. The students were demonstrating against a 15% rise in fees for new students proposed by University administration (who had previously attempted to raise fees by first 90%, and then 45%, before backing down in the face of student demonstrations).

On September 11th, traders demonstrated in Jinja (Jinja district) at delays in completing roadworks. The traders blocked roads with stones, and engaged in 'running battles' with the police. [size=no report]

On September 11th, vendors stormed the municipality offices in Kabale (Kabale district), following a ban on road-side selling of food. The vendors also accused security forces of assaulting them when the ban was first implemented. [size=50]

On or before September 11th, police and students clashed at Makerere University (Kampala). The students were demonstrating against a 15% rise in fees for new students proposed by University administration (who had previously attempted to raise fees by first 90%, and then 45%, before backing down in the face of student demonstrations).

Arrests: On September 11th, police dispersed a gathering of youth said to be organising an event to celebrate the return of Bobi Wine MP (note that no date is scheduled for his return). An organiser - Ibrahim Agaba - was arrested by police, who warned youth not to become involved in 'illegal demonstrations'. The same day, Wine's bodyguard - Eddie Mutwe (the alias of Edward Sebuufu) - was charged with treason alongside one other man, for their alleged involvement in the events in Arua on August 13th. Separately, Francis Zaake MP (a political ally of Bobi Wine, who was also detained and (likely) tortured with Wine), was reported to be in a critical condition in a hospital in India.

On September 10th, a mob attacked a landlord at Njagala Bwami village (Nakaseke district; coordinates for Namasuba used at precision 2), after he had sent men to destroy the villagers crops. The landlord and his driver were seriously wounded in the attack; 11 people have been arrested. [size=small]

On September 10th, protesters of the village of Kigamba-Kasubi stormed the mayor's office at Masaka (Masaka district), following efforts by the state to evict them from disputed land, to build a hospital. [size=50]

On September 8th, unknown gunmen riding motobikes shot dead the suspended Buyende District Police Commander Muhammad Kirumira and an unidentified woman (initially reported to be his wife) who were travelling in their car in Bulenga (Wakiso district). The maverick commander was on trial for various abuses of office.

On September 4th, South Sudanese refugees based in the Bidi Bidi refugee camp (Yumbe district) organised a peaceful protests in response to a lack of food rations (which one refugee claimed had not been delivered for two months).

On September 3, in Pajule Town Council (Aruu, Pader), youths staged a demonstration and blocked the Lacani protesting against its impassable state. They claim the road was last maintained by the district works and technical department in 2014.

On or before September 2nd, clashes between two South Sudanese clans took place in Nyumazi refugee camp (coordinates for Nyumazi town, Northern region, used), leaving 12 injured. The incident was sparked by a rumour started by the jealous ex-lover of a woman, which escalated into a larger altercation.

On August 31st, demonstrators burnt tires and furniture on the road at Namulesa village (Jinja district), in protest at a delayed response by authorities to a fire which killed two children. Police dispersed the demonstrators with live rounds and tear gas. [size=no report]

On August 31st, riots broke out in the Kamwokya neighborhood of Kampala, in protest at the rearrest of Bobi Wine the previous day. Rioters clashed with riot police and UPDF soldiers during the morning, before being dispersed.
On August 31st, and amidst riots in Kampala, a journalist with the NBS television station - Joshua Mujunga - was beaten by security forces.

Arrests: On August 30th, Bobi Wine was once again arrested by the Ugandan authorities (recorded here as Police Forces) as he tried to board a plane to the US at Entebbe airport. Riots broke out the following day over his re-arrest. The MP was able to board his flight the following day.

On or before August 28th, soldiers involved in acts of violence against civilians and MPs associated with the incident in Arua on August 13th have been arrested. The UPDF spokesman did not provide further details on those arrested, nor how many had been arrested. On September 18th, the UPDF announced that those soldiers implicated in abuses will soon face a court martial.

On 27th August, youths gathered on the highway between Gulu and Kampala, and allegedly threw stones at police and obstructed traffic. This was seemingly in support of Bobi Wine and other MPs who were released on bail from Gulu court. Riot police backed up by UPDF engaged the protesters, and arrested 46 of them, detaining them in Luwero district police station.

On August 23rd, youth supporters of Paul Mwiru (MP for Jinja, who had been recently arrested in connection with events in Arua) burned tires on roads in Jinja (Jinja district), demanding the release of the MP. Police and UPDF dispersed the demonstrators. [size=no report]
On August 23rd, police rescued a woman who was being attacked by a lynch mob in Kasese (Kasese district), who accused her of killing her child. [size=no report]

On 23 August, rioting youths clashed witht the police in Bukalagi, Gomba. The youths, armed with clubs and machetes, lit bonfires and blocked roads to protest Bobi Wine's trial. The police fired into the crowd, killing a boda boda driver.

On August 22nd, youth (suspected of being supporters of Paul Mwiru (MP for Jinja), who had been recently arrested in connection with events in Arua) threw stones at a bus transporting prisoners to the courthouse in Jinja (Jinja district). Police dispersed the youth by firing live rounds. [size=no report]
On 21 August, mourners at the funeral of a protester killed by a police bullet on 19 Aug rioted and threw rocks at the Assistant Police Commissioner, who tried to attend the funeral in Mityana.

On 20 August, police and military broke up a group of protesters marching from Katwe to Usafi Market against the arrest of Bobi Wine. The security forces fired live bullets into the crowd. 1 protester was shot dead.

On 20 August, people protested at Kiseka Market and around central Kampala against the arrest of Bobi Wine, setting fire to tires and wooden pallets, blocking traffic, and throwing stones at policemen. The police fired tergas and shots in the air to disperse the crowd, and then called for military support. Traders had to close their shops. 30 people were arrested. Hundreds of civilians were forced to kneel for hours in the centre of town, while the soldiers conducted searches.
On 20 August, observer journalists were arrested as they returned to their offices, in Mulago, Kampala. They were beaten and the soldiers used pliers to torture them.

On August 19th, police shot at a taxi as it left Mityana (Mityana district, coordinates used at precision 2 as the vehicle may have been outside the town when the incident occurred), after it failed to stop for an inspection. One person died, and five were wounded (two seriously).

On August 19th, a Basongora militia attacked Banyarwanda civilians in the villages of Kayanja I and Kayanja II (Kasese district, coordinates for Kitswamba at precision 2), torching seven dwellings. This was the second attack on the villages by these perpetrators during the month. The attack relates to a land dispute.

On 19 August, a group of people barricaded the highway in Mityana to protest the arrest of the Mityana MP, Zaake with Bobi Wine. Police dispersed the crowd using live ammunition. 1 person was shot dead and 5 people were injured.
On 18 August, police fired live ammunition and teargas to disperse a crowd of protesters blocking the roads in Mukono. Protests had erupted in response to the arrest of Bobi Wine.

source: Chimp Reports; Daily Monitor (Uganda); Weekly Observer
notes: On 16 and 17 August, residents in Kamwokya suburb in Kampala protested against the arrest of Bobi Wine. They lit bonfires and blockaded the roads. The police fired teargas on the protesters and arrested a number of youths.

On August 16th, market vendors clashed with police at Mbale central market (Mbale district), with the latter using tear gas and live rounds to disperse the demonstrators (who were attempting to block the installation of a mobile phone mast on top of the market building). [size=no report]
On 16 August, residents of Rupa protested against a land grab by a prominent businessman and some ministers.

source: Chimp Reports; Daily Monitor (Uganda); Weekly Observer
notes: On 16 and 17 August, residents in Kamwokya suburb in Kampala protested against the arrest of Bobi Wine. They lit bonfires and blockaded the roads. The police fired teargas on the protesters and arrested a number of youths.
