Following his arrest on 14 August, it was reported that FDC leader Bobi Wine was severely tortured in the Gulu barracks while in detention, until he could not walk.
On August 15th, youth beat the mayor of Arua and threw stones at his vehicle as he fled, at Arua town (Arua district). Police who were present did not intervene. [size=10]
On 15 August, supporters of Wadri, an independent candidate in the Arua by election, rioted and smashed the windscreen of a municipality official's car. The police intervened.

In August, over 30 soldiers from the South Sudanese army (SSPDF, formerly SPLA) crossed the border into Uganda at Ngomoromo, claiming parts of Lamwo district as South Sudanese territory. After reaching the area, they were accused of molesting women and stealing from the local population. As of early April 2019, the size of the base has increased to around 180 soldiers, and includes heavy artillery. The soldiers are reported to be from Division 7 of the Cobra Battalion, and are commanded by Lt. Colonel Ruben Mayom Chol.

Arrests: On 14 August, FDC leader Bobi Wine was arrested in Arua, following an FDC demonstration the previous day. He was held in the Gulu barracks, where he was severely tortured, until he could not walk. He was initially charged with possessing illegal weapons by a military court but the charges were dropped. He was then charged with treason but granted bail on August 27th along with 11 others (including several MPs). The court ordered Kassiano Wadri, the newly elected MP for Arua, not to go to his constituency.
Security measures: On 14 August, police and military were heavily deployed across Arua town, to maintain security ahead of the election.
On 13 Augst, the police arrested journalists at the Pacific Hotel in Arua after riots erupted in the area. They were severely beaten and their equipment was confiscated.

actor2: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Presidential Security Unit
notes: On 13 August, opposition FDC and ruling party NRM supporters were both campaigning in Arua town. The presidential security unit attempted to clear the FDC supporters for Museveni's convoy, using live ammunition. The FDC supporters retaliated by throwing rocks at the presidential connvoy and at the NRM supporters. The driver of a prominent FDC leader, Bobi Wine, was shot and killed by the presidential security unit. 34 people were arrested during the protest, including opposition MPs and candidates. Some soldiers were arrested around August 28th.
In the week of 11 August, a crowd of people mobbed a thief in Katabi, in Entebbe. A soldier tried to intervene, and was also attacked and beaten.

actor1: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Uganda Wildlife Authority
notes: On August 10th, Wildlife rangers shot three civilians at Mount Elgon National Park (Kween district), killing one and wounding the other two. The circumstances surrounding the attack are unclear.

On August 9th, residents of Nyakahanga cell protested at the Electoral Commission offices in Makanga (Kabale district), storming the offices in order to express their disgruntlement at the lack of LC1 elections in the cell. [size=50]
On or before August 9th, police were alleged to have tortured an LC3 chairman at Mbarara police station (Mbarara district), in order to extract a confession for livestock theft.
On 9 August, residents protested in Rupa, against a plan to build a cement factory in the area.
In the week of 8 August, residents in Igayaza stormed the office of the district Internal Security Officer (DISO) to protest the arrest of 2 people accused of plotting a rebellion.

At an unspecified time in early August (coded as Aug 8th at time precision 3), a Basongora militia attacked Banyarwanda civilians in the villages of Kayanja I and Kayanja II (Kasese district, coordinates for Kitswamba at precision 2), beating an unspecified number of residents. The attack relates to a land dispute.
On 7 August, a pastor was lynched and killed by a mob in Pagirinya, Adjumani. She was accused of practising witchcraft.
On 6 August, students at a school in Omel, Gulu county, rioted and attacked the headmaster to protest the failure to release results. The headmaster was hospitalised with severe injuries.

On August 4th or 5th, a mob armed with basic weapons (including bows and arrows) attacked three suspected cattle thieves in Lia parish (Moroto district, coordinates for Katikekile used at precision 2). Police intervened to rescue the three suspects. [size=no report]
On August 4th, a UPDF soldier killed three civilians at a nightclub in the Kabedopong area of Gulu town. The motivation for the attack is unclear. The soldier has been arrested.

On August 3rd, residents of Buwampa protested pollution at a distillery site in Buwampa (Buikwe district). The demonstrators damaged parts of the facility, and assaulted drivers working for the company. [size=1000]

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On 3 Aug, unidentified armed men, wearing Congolese military uniforms, beat and attacked civilians in Kanungu, and abducted 1, for whom they asked a ransom.
On 3 August, attendees at a public event in Arua became rowdy as they started to loot equipment and block roads. The police fired teargas and bullets into the crowd. 2 people were hospitalised.

assoc_actor_1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On 3 August, 3 men travelling near the Southern Gate Army Barracks in Kanungu were ambushed by unidentified attackers, some of whom were wearing DRC military uniforms. The attackers shot and injured 2 of the men and abducted the 3rd.

On August 1st, students at Nyakitoko Secondary School (Buhweju district) demonstrated against the headmaster of the school, demanding his resignation. Police officers shot dead an 18 year-old student, and wounded a 22 year-old student, as they attempted to suppress the protests. Two police officers have been arrested.
On 30 July, there were demonstrations at the Kasese LC office to demand the creation of new sub-counties in Busongora.

On 30 July, members of a local NGO at a protest in Sheema municipality against the election of a local MP allegedly beat a journalist and destroyed his equipment. He was sent to the hospital with injuries, including from strangulation.

On 28th or 29th July, a lynch mob killed a man suspected to be a current or past member of the (now defunt) Flying Squad Police Unit at Natete (Wakiso) on the outskirts of Kampala. The man had a track record of extorting civilians in the areas he was stationed and was found with looted items.

On or before July 28th, police and UPDF soldiers used tear gas and live rounds to disperse FDC demonstrators outside of the tally station in Nebbi (Nebbi district), following allegations that the NRM had taken the parliamentary seat through foul play. (Note: actor 2 coded as protesters, as it is unclear whether they were engaged in violent activities). [size=no report]

On 27th July, police clashed with an armed group (whom the police described as armed robbers, but were in military uniform - coded as UAG) at Namuyago swamp in Kadimuko sub-district (coordinates for Kadimukoli, Budaka district, used). One member of the group was shot and killed; his two colleagues escaped.

assoc_actor_2: NRM: National Resistance Movement; Government of Uganda (1986-)
notes: On July 27, 2018, a mob attacked an NRM MP who was seen attempting to bribe voters in Butambula (Bugiri district). The MP fought back, before firing pepper spray at nearby journalists. Two journalists were injured in the violence. Police intervened to rescue the MP. [size=small]
On 26 July, protesters filled the Mbale High Court to await the judgment on the age limit ruling.

On July 25th, supporters of an independent mayoral candidate clashed with those supporting the NRM candidate in Kotido town (Kotido district). Police used tear gas to disperse the rioters (who clashed with sticks and stones, which injured around 40 people), and made a number of arrests, including of NRM members the following day. [size=no report]
On the night of July 24 to 25, armed men from Uganda reportedly arrested four Congolese fishermen on Lake Albert and tortured one of them who was sent to the hospital. They also stole their material.
During the municipal elections in the week of 23 July, UPC supporters attacked and beat NRM supporters in Apac. One NRM activist was hospitalised.

actor1: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Fisheries Protection Unit
notes: On July 23rd, a UPDF soldier shot dead a fisherman at Kusu landing site (Kalangala district, coordinates for Luku used at precision 2). The fisherman was attempting to evade arrest, as soldiers were sweeping the area for illegal fishing activities.
On 23 July, students at the Unyama National Teachers College in Gulu rioted when student guild elections were postponed. 22 students were injured in the clashes between competing student groups.

actor1: JEEMA: Justice, Education, Economic Revitalization, Morality and African Unity
notes: On 23 July, 2 NRM supporters were stabbed as they were leaving a rally in Bugiri. It is believed that they were stabbed by youths from one of the leading opposition parties, JEEMA. Both victims wree hospitalised.
On 23 July, the FDC candidate for the Mparo mayoral seat in Rukiga district was ambushed and beaten by unidentified attackers. He is currently in hospital.

On 22 July, a refugee in Palorinya Refugee camp was shot dead by unidentified gunmen. The refugee was a South Sudanese government soldier, who defected to the SPLA-IO, before joining the National Salvation Front. Police suspect that his attackers are either SPLA-IO or National Salvation Front militants.

actor1: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Fisheries Protection Unit
notes: On July 21st, UPDF FPU soldiers beat an unspecified number of female fishermen at Kigungu landing site (Kalangala district, coordinates for Luku used at precision 2). The soldiers were sweeping the area for illegal fishing activities.

assoc_actor_1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo); Vigilante Group (Uganda); Vigilante Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On 21 July 2018, angry people from both sides of the Uganda/DRC border allegedly attacked and killed 3 soldiers at a customs post in Vurra on suspicion of robbery.
On 21 July, a local politician was heckling a candidate at an NRM rally in Kafunjo Health Center II. Soldiers tried to remove him from the rally, and then shot him.

On July 19th, and following the detention of an independent candidate for the Bugiri parliamentary seat, supporters of the detained candidate blocked roads in Bugiri (Bugiri district). Police dispersed the demonstrators (coded as protesters, as the source doesn't specify the means used to block the road) with tear gas. [size=no report]

On July 18th, two groups of South Sudanese refugees rioted at Ayilo-1 camp (Adjumani district, coordinates for Pakele used at precision 2), following the death of a girl, and accusations that she was gang raped. Police dispersed the rioters, and made six arrests (including of three Ugandans involved in the clashes). [size=no report]

On July 18th, striking students destroyed property at a school in an unspecified location in Matany sub-county (Napak district, coordinates for Lokopo used at prec2). There is no clear motive behind the demonstration, and students fled the area following the incident. [size=200]
On 18 July, a group of MPs and protesters marched with activist Bobi Wine, to protest his arrest. The police arrested a number of protesters.

assoc_actor_1: JEEMA: Justice, Education, Economic Revitalization, Morality and African Unity
notes: On 18 July, police officers fired after JEEMA supporters at a rally threw stones at them. 1 person was killed by the gunshots.
On 18 July, FDC supporters travelling from a rally in Kashozi for the Sheema election were surrounded and beaten by NRM supporters and security forces.
On 17 July, police officers were investigating a robbery in a village in Gisoro. A crowd of villagers rioted, so the police opened fire. 1 villager was killed and 2 were injured.

On July 15th, a team of police officers surrounded a bar in Maliba (Kasese district), and shot dead an off-duty soldier (Actor 2 coded as civilian, with assoc actor2 UPDF). There is no clear motive for the attack.
On July 13th, a soldier shot dead a 16 year-old boy in Rukoki (Kasese district). There is no further information.

actor1: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: On July 13th, suspected SPLM-IO militants from South Sudan raided Lutuoko village in Lamwo district. The raiders shot dead a civilian and stole eight cattle, four of which were recovered after a UPDF patrol traced the attackers footsteps.
On 11 July, 200 villagers who had been evicted from their land in Apaa began a sit-in protest outside the UN offices in Gulu.

On 11 July, protesters marched in Kampala to protest against the social media tax. The police tried to disperse the protest with teargas and live ammunition, so the protesters rioted and threw stones at the police.

source: Human Rights Network for Journalists Uganda
notes: During the week of 11 July, mobile money operators in Katakwi held a protest against tariffs. 3 journalists covering the protest were arrested.

source: Human Rights Network for Journalists Uganda
notes: During the week of 11 July, journalists covering an NRM meeting in Apac began to interview UPC youths as well. The NRM youths grew angry and assaulted the journalists.

On July 10th, NRM supporters clashed with supporters of another political party (or parties) in Tank Hill village (Bushenyi district, coordinates for Bushenyi used at precision 2), after electoral fraud was alleged to have been committed. Police and UPDF separated the groups. [size=no report]

On July 10th, residents of Katanga slum in Kampala demonstrated and threw stones, claiming that an LC1 candidate was not from the neighborhood and ineligible to run. Police used tear gas and live rounds to disperse the crowds. [size=no report]

On July 10th, three police officers fired over the heads of a crowd of demonstrators throwing rocks (coded as rioters), who were demonstrating against delayed results in Kikaya (Kampala district). A demonstrator was hit in the leg, as a result of a stray bullet. A police officer has been arrested. [size=400]
On July 10th, demonstrators threw stones at police in Masanafu (Kampala district), alleging that electoral fraud was being committed in the area. There is no further information. [size=no report]
On July 10th, police rescued a presiding officer from a mob in Luwero town (Luwero district), who alleged electoral fraud was being committed. Police then dispersed the crowds. [size=no report]

On July 10th, police and UPDF rescued a presiding officer who was being beaten by a mob of DP supporters, after she incorrectly announced results, awarding his opponent the LC1 chairmanship. [size=no report]

On 10 July, during LC1 elections, violence broke out in Kawempe village. Voters believed that a candidate had ferried extra supporters from other villages. They rioted and began beating up the electoral officials when they were rescued by police.

On July 8th, supporters of the NRM LC1 candidate rioted in Gamba village (Wakiso, coordinates for Nansana used at precision 2), claiming that he had been poisoned. Police dispersed the crowds with gunfire, after they attempted to attack rival candidates. [size=no report]
On July 8th, a vigilante mob buried alive a suspected thief at Kitoonma village in Irima parish (coordinates used; Ibanda district). The victim died of suffocation. [size=small]

On July 8th, the UPDF bodyguards of the MP for Ntoroko District assaulted road workers at Makondo Bridge who were working for a construction company that had been contracted to build the Kakara-Rwebisengo road. The soldiers as well as the MP are under investigation, and were summoned to court in early November of the same year.

On or before July 4th, a mob prevented police from making an arrest at the Arua Park area of Kampala. Police fired gunshots in the air to disperse the crowd, though two bullets hit the crowd, causing two injuries. [size=no report]
'One male national INGO staff member while on leave in Kampala, was caught amidst a riot while travelling. Police fired to disperse the crowd and the staff member was shot in the leg.'

actor1: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Internal Security Organisation
notes: On 2 July, officers from the Internal Security Organisation kidnapped cell phone technicians from MTN towers in Kampala. They were interrogated about former Police Chief Kayihura's cell phone calls.

On or before July 2nd, sugarcane growers demonstrated at the sugar factor in Kakira (Jinja district), at the imposition of new taxes. The demonstrators blocked the gates with rocks, and threw stones at the building. [size=no report]
On July 2nd, researchers working on a project on climate change and agriculture stormed the district HQ in Moroto (Moroto district), following the non-payment of allowances. [size=100]

During the week between June 27th and July 3rd, protesters demonstrated against a police officer from Kibanda (Rakai district), following his role in an assault on a woman in Kakuuto sub-county of Kyotera district, resulting in the arrest of the officer. (Note that the source does not specify where the protests took place; coordinates for Kibanda used at precision 2. One event coded at time precision 2).
On 30 June, hundreds of protesters marched in Kampala to protest violence against women.

On June 27th, students rioted at St Leo's College in Kyegobe (Kabarole district), following a dispute over the composition of the school football team. Students were prevented from attacking the headteacher when police intervened, using live gunfire to disperse the students. [size=small]

On June 27th, a lynch mob (armed with sticks and stones) clashed with police for around two hours in Lira town (Lira district). The mob was attempting to kill a suspected thief, and wanted to the police to hand over the suspect to them. Police used tear gas and live rounds to disperse the mob, with a stray bullet wounding a nearby vendor. [size=no report]

assoc_actor_2: JEEMA: Justice, Education, Economic Revitalization, Morality and African Unity
notes: On 26 June, NRM and FDC youths beat 3 JEEMA activists who were campaigning in Bugiri. One of the activists was stabbed in the stomach and is severely injured. The police claimed the incident was criminal, but the opposition candidate insists that it was political violence.

On 25 June, the Kabale district chairperson attacked and beat a journalist at the Voice of Kigezi offices in Kabale town. The chairperson was angry because the journalist had reported unfavourably on a district meeting.

On June 21st, pupils demonstrated in Standard High School in Kisoro town (Kisoro district), following a disputed election for position of head prefect. Students threw stones, damaging windows in school buildings. Police arrested 18 students. [size=small]
On 21 June, students clashed with police officers in Mbarara. The students were protesting their eviction from a school. The police fired teargas to disperse the crowd.

On June 20th, demonstrators dug holes in the road at an unspecified location(s) in Bungokho-Mutoto sub-county (Mbale district, coordinates used at precision 2), and stormed a meeting at the sub-county HQ . Police dispersed the demonstrators, who were protesting the poor quality of roads and bridges in the area. [size=no report]

On June 20th, pupils of Oleico Primary School marched in Kumi town (Kumi district), demanding that six of their teachers (who had been arrested for allegedly damaging a car belonging to a woman involved in a land dispute with the school) be released. [size=127]

On June 19, in Mbarara town (Mbarara, Mbarara), Chieftaincy of Military Intelligence-CMI arrested Jaffar Magyezi, the Mbarara District Police Commander for suspicion of various offenses, including espionage, organized crime and illegally extraditing refugees.

On June 19th, a lynch mob killed a murder suspect and burned two of his houses in Ominai A village (Kaberamaido district, coordinates for Alwa used at precision 2). Police arrived too late to intervene. [size=no report]

On June 17th, police fired live rounds above the heads of youth who were attempting to gather fuel from a overturned fuel truck in Butende (Iganga district) (note that a fire was present in the area, from another overturned truck). The youth then clashed with the police, who they accused of attempting to siphon fuel themselves, though there is no information regarding injuries. [size=no report]

assoc_actor_1: Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan)
assoc_actor_2: Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan)
notes: On 17 June, riots erupted between Nuer and Dinka refugees in the Rhino Camp Settlement during a world cup match. 4 people were killed and 19 injured. The police have confiscated the sticks and clubs used in the clashes.

On June 15, in Kampala city (Kampala, Kampala), two stick bombs planted by unidentified actors were discovered at Plot 66 Kampala Road. The police responded and took away the two suspect items for proper disposal.

Around June, eight senior police and military officers were arrested as part of a purge of suspected Rwandan elements in the Ugadan security services. The men are accused of facilitating the return of two dissidents to Rwanda in 2013 (one of whom has since been sentenced to life in prison, the other has 'disappeared'), and for arranging arms supplies for the pro-government vigalante group Boda Boda 2010. They were charged by a military court in Makindye on January 8th, 2019.

On 14 June, people gathered in Kisoro town with placards to protest the arrest of former police chief Kyihura the day before. Police was deployed throughout the town to prevent the protest from being held. The arrest came a few days after other senior police officers were arrested over unclear reasons.

On June 13th, two suspected thieves were killed by a mob in or near Mbulire village in Bigasa sub-county (Bukomansimbi district, coordinates for Kasenyi used at prec2). One suspect has been arrested and jailed, and two other men are at large. [size=small]

On 13 June, police arrested Mukono MP, Betty Nambooze, in conjunction with the murder of MP Abirige the previous week. Her supporters protested outside the Jinja Road Police Station in Kampala, where she was held.
On June 12th, 15 truck drivers under police detention for transporting banned timber demonstrated in Gulu town (Gulu district), claiming they were unfairly detained. [size=15]

actor1: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
assoc_actor_1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
notes: On the night of June 12-13, a mixed FARDC-police patrol killed 2 fishermen in Lake Albert.

On 10 June, locals stormed the Arua Airfield, where the bodies of MP Abiriga and his brother killed two days prior in Kampala were delivered. The crowds seized the bodies and marched in the streets with them, detroying property and assaulting the mourners. The police fired into the crowd, killing at least one protester. The NRM later blamed the riot on the opposition, FDC.
On 8 June, truck drivers in Kabale stormed the Kabale mayor's office to demand the public goods in truck park.

On June 8th, police dispersed protesters (comprising residents, boda boda drivers, and mechanics) who blocked a road in Mbale (Mbale district) in protest against its poor quality (note: the means through which it was blocked were unspecified, actor 1 coded as protesters). Two shopkeepers were wounded after being hit by a tear gas canister that penetrated the walls of the shop. Five people were arrested by police. [size=hundreds]
On 8 June, an NRM MP, Ibrahim Abiriga, was assassinated with his brother by unidentified gunmen near his home in Kampala.

On 7 June, residents of Nyendo town demonstrated against the poor state of the road. The police intercepted the demonstration and fired teargas, so the protesters turned violent and threw stones at the police and burned tires.
On 7 June a pro-Kadaga NRM youth disappeared. It is believed that he was abducted by security agents. He is feared to be dead.

On 6 June, residents in Busia rioted outside the police station, demanding that the police release a suspected kidnapper to the crowd, so that they could punish him. The crowd threw stones at the police and blocked the roads. The police fired teargas and bullets into the crowd. 1 person was shot dead and 1 person was seriously injured.
On June 5th, rice farmers stormed the District HQ in Kalangala (Kalangala district), following a ban on rice farming in the district. [size=no report]
On 5 June, a group of activists protested at the Police Headquarters in Kampala. Police arrested 5 of the protesters. The protesters were calling for police action against kidnapping in Uganda.
On June 5, in Kawempe town (Jinja, Wakiso), an angry mob beat two people accused of abducting a girl, leaving them severely injured.
On 4 June, truck drivers in Mbale protested against the municipality, because it had incorrectly awarded a tender for loading. The police attended the protest in case it turned violent.

actor1: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Prison Guards
notes: Assumed on June 4, in Kampala city (Kampala, Kampala), police are suspected of torturing nine suspects imprisoned in Luzira prison for killing Susan Magara in February.

During the week of 30 May, a Christian group held a meeting at Kigobero Grounds, in Iganga town. Muslims and Christians at the meeting clashed when Muslims accused the Christian pastors of demoralising Islam. The police intervened to break up the riots.

On or before May 30th, a mass grave was found at Kasubi on the outskirts of Gulu town. It is believed to contain the remains of Holy Spirit Movement fighters who were killed in a clash with government troops in 1987. The number of bodies is unclear, but one source says around 17 remains are present.
On 24 May, South Sudanese refugees in the Omugo Refugee Camp rioted and ransacked the UN stores to access food, which has been scarce. The police broke up the riot and arrested 9 people. [size=200]

On 24 May, rioters attacked a police station in Namutumba. The police fired teargas and fought running battles with the rioters. The riot happened because the police arrested a man accused of kidnapping children. The residents of Namutumba stormed the police station to try to lynch the suspect.

Arrests: Following the kidnapping of Ugandan fishermen by Congolese Mayi Mayi militia on Lake Edward, Ugandan police arrested 26 Congolese fishermen on the Ugandan side of Lake Edward, in Rukungiri province.
On May 22, in Kampala city (Kampala, Kampala), Inspector General of Police (IGP) Ochola halted licensing of private firearms to civilians.
On May 20th, a suspected goat rustler was lynched by a mob in Kyesiga village (Hoima district), and his body set on fire. [size=no report]

On May 19th, clashes between residents of Alango village and police broke out after police ordered the residents to vacate the disputed land (coordinates for Abala Parish, Alebtong district, used at precision 2). A female demonstrator was wounded in the hand when police opened fire. [size=no report]

On 19 May, residents of Ganyinayo rioted and destroyed the property of a businessman, Vincent Mugisha, who is accused of grabbing land in the village for development. The police and military used teargas and live bullets to disperse the rioters, who were armed with pangas and spears.

On May 19th, a suspected motorbike thief was lynched at Kiganda village in Bujumbura subcounty (Hoima district, coordinates for Kibingo used at precision 2). The mob then set his body and vehicle on fire. [size=small]
On 19 May, Mayi Mayi militia from the DRC kidnapped 6 Ugandan fishermen who were fishing on Lake Edward, near Rweshama village.

On May 14th, raiders from the Irarak clan attacked Ojukot village in the vicinity of Otuboi (Kaberamaido district, coordinates used at precision 2). They lit fire to a number of dwellings, and stole 30 animals. The attack was in revenge for the murder of a daughter of the clan by her husband in the same village.

On May 11th, UPDF soldiers clashed with a raiding group (suspected of coming from South Sudan, and coded as such), killing one raider. The event occurred at an unspecified location in Pobar Parish (Lamwo district), and was part of a series of cattle raids in the area that day.

On May 7th, 200 students from Busoga Universoty (Iganga town) demonstrated against the University when they realised they were unlikely to be able to sit their final exams (the University had its license revoked, and was in the process of being taken over by the government). Eight students were arrested the following day, though no reason for the arrests is given in the source.

On May 6th, a woman suspected of killing her two children survived an attack by a lynch mob. The event occurred in Bugahe village of Chahi subcounty (Kisoro district, coordinates for Bushoka used at precision 2). The woman was badly beaten, but police intervened in time to prevent the crowd from killing her. [size=small]
On May 6th, a lynch mob killed a suspected thief at an unspecified location in Kigorobya subcounty (Hoima district, coordinates used at precision 2), and then set the body on fire. [size=small]
04 May. A human rights worker was attacked by four armed people at his home in the outskirts of Kampala.

During the week beginning April 30th, UPDF soldiers evicted over 1,000 fisherman from the small islands Makusa and Lwamunyo (coordinates for Entebbe, Wakiso, used). The residents complained that the soldiers destroyed much of their property and means of livelihood (the two islands supported fishing communities), and were concerned at the lack of adequate alternative living arrangements offered by the government.
On May 2nd, a police officer shot dead a civilian at a bar in Nakawa (Kampala), in disputed circumstances.

On April 30th, the Hoima-Kaiso Tonya road was blocked after striking workers demonstrated, placing stones and logs on to the road, in an area close to Bulemwa (Hoima district). The demonstrators (who worked for the Shandong Taikai Power Engineering Company) were protesting the absence of pay for the past week. [size=no report]

Security measures: On 29 April, police and military stormed a mosque in Makindye as part of a crack-down on mosques following the discovery of hostages and arms in a mosque in Kisenyi. It is unclear if arrests were made in Makindye or if any violence ensued.

On 28 April, police and military forces raided Usafi Mosque in Kisenyi, to free women and children from the community who had been kidnapped and held hostage by the mosque. During the gunfight, two Muslim militants were killed and 36 were arrested. An arms cache was discovered in the mosque. Some of the 36 arrested are believed to be ADF militants.
On 26 April, rioters burned down materials at the Kisekka market. Police was shown as present in the area but it is unclear if they engaged the rioters.
On 26 April, residents of Nyendo town blocked the Nyendo-Masaka road with burning logs and tires. When the police and military came to break up the riot, the rioters threw stones at them.
On 25 April, demonstrators protested against poor service delivery and president Museveni in Kashambya
On 25 April, demonstrators protested against poor service delivery and president Museveni in Kamwezi
On 25 April, demonstrators protested against poor service delivery and president Museveni in Muhanga

On 25th April, residents of Nyagakenke village marched to the Kisoro District offices and protested. They demanded the release of the body of a man shot by Mgahinga National Park rangers on April 23rd. Following the protest, four suspects were arrested. [size=200]
On 25 April, demonstrators protested against poor service delivery and president Museveni in Rwamucucu

On April 24th, a police officer shot and wounded two civilians in Kikumikikumi zone (coordinates for Wandegeya, Kampala, used). The victims were the girlfriend of the police officer, and a man who he suspected of being romantically involved with his girlfriend. Both were shot in the legs. The officer has been arrested for attempted murder.

On April 23nd, residents from six villages in Bwijanga subcounty blocked the Kigumba-Bulima road at an unspecified location (coordinates for Bwijanga town, Masindi district, used at precision 2), to highlight the poor quality of the road. Residents used logs, and dug a hole in the road. [size=no report]

actor1: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Uganda Wildlife Authority
notes: On 23rd April, park rangers in the Mgahinga National Park (Kisoro district) shot a man dead. They claim that they believed he was a poacher, however, local residents claimed that the man was gathering firewood and was clearly disabled, so could not have been confused with a poacher.

actor1: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Presidential Security Unit
notes: On 23 April, soldiers in the First Lady's guard beat a university professor at Makerere University.

On April 22nd, a police officer shot an 18 year-old man (the source implies the victim was shot in the genitals), with the victim dying of his wounds on the following day. The event occurred in Kikajjo zone (Wakiso). There is no established motive for the attack, and the officer has been charged with murder.

On April 21st, a lynch mob killed a man at an unspecified location in Abim subcounty (Abim district, coordinates for Abim used at precision 2) as he travelled to Kanu village in the subcounty. The man was accused of stealing two goats. [size=small]

During March and April 2018, soldiers evicted over 6,000 villagers from their lands in Pakwach district. The soldiers burned down huts, beat the villagers severely, and stole livestock and property. This land has now been occupied by a senior UPDF official. Coded as two events per month with a date precision of 2.

On April 19th, a lynch mob killed two men in Awielem village in Adekokwok subcounty (Lira district, coordinates for Boroboro used at precision 2), on the suspicion that they had stolen a goat. [size=small]
On 17 April, residents on William Street in Kampala gathered to protest the broken sewage system, however the police prevented them from marching.
On 17 April, clashes between protesting students and police at Makerere University continued.
On 17 April, MP Paul Mwiru and his supporters demonstrated outside the Kira police station to protest against the arrest of opposition supporters. The police dispersed the protesters.
On 16 April, protesting students clashed with the police at Makerere University. The police arrested 6 students.

On April 15th, residents of Bugomora village protested at an unspecified location along the road linking Nyabubare (Bushenyi district, coordinates used) to Kizinda, to highlight the very poor condition of the road. The source notes that demonstrators blocked the road, but does not specify how (actor 1 coded as protesters), and that police intervened to end the protest. [size=no report]
On 11 April, youth marched to the High Court in Mbale to protest the age limit bill. They were intercepted and prevented from marching by the police.
During the week of 11 April, residents of Mukoko village attacked and killed a man who was suspected of attacking and robbing people.

During March and April 2018, soldiers evicted over 6,000 villagers from their lands in Pakwach district. The soldiers burned down huts, beat the villagers severely, and stole livestock and property. This land has now been occupied by a senior UPDF official. Coded as two events per month with a date precision of 2.

actor1: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
notes: On April 7th, a man described as 'loitering' in the vicinity of Moroto airstrip (Moroto district) was shot dead by a member of the LDU, who was guarding the airstrip.

On April 7th, a police officer attempted to prevent a student from being attacked by a rival student football team in Mutolere (Kisoro district), and shot one of the attackers in the leg. The officer was placed under arrest. [size=no report]
On April 6th, a lynch mob killed a man in Kibungo (Rubanda district, coordinates for Kaara used at precision 2), on suspicion that he had killed his father earlier that day. [size=no report]

actor2: Mutiny of Military Forces of Uganda (1986-)
notes: On April 6th, a UPDF deserter attacked a man using hand weapons in Nyagicyebe village (coordinates for Rwaramba parish, Kisoro district, used at precision 2). A mob formed and killed the soldier. The motive for the attack is unclear. [size=small]
On 5 April, police and rioters engaged in running battles near a refugee camp in Arua. The police arrested an LCIII Chairman and 6 other Ugandans and accused them of inciting riots against refugees.
On 5 April, residents in Mityana rioted to protest against the poor state of roads. They barricaded the roads and burned car tyres. The police intervened to contain the rioters.
On 4 April, suspected SPLA soldiers who had crossed into Uganda clashed with UPDF and the Uganda Police Force in Dufile. The Ugandan forces defeated the SPLA. There were no reported casualties.
On 4 April, suspected SPLA soldiers who had crossed into Uganda clashed with UPDF and the Uganda Police Force in Metu. The Ugandan forces defeated the SPLA. There were no reported casualties.
During the week of 28 March, residents of Kyotera tried to lynch a man accused of raping a young girl. They stormed his house and attacked him with clubs. The police intervened and arrested the man.
On 27 March, subjects of the Busoga Kingdom staged a peaceful demonstration in Kamuli against the State Minister for Lands, whom they accuse of disrespecting the Busoga king.

assoc_actor_2: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-); Military Forces of Uganda (1986-)
notes: On 27 March, Uganda Revenue Authority officials were attacked by a crowd of Boda Boda drivers when they tried to enforce registration in Yumbe. Their private security forces fired into the air. The crowds then attacked and destroyed cars and property. The police and military had to be brought in to calm the town.
On 26 March, students at Kabale University marched to the office of the Resident District Commissioner to protest the expensive fees.
On 26 March, there was a peaceful demonstration at the Nakawa Chief Magistrates Court to protest the release of a professor accused of pouring acid on his lover.
On 23 March, soldiers carrying out a forceful eviction of residents in Apaa shot at the residents. One person died and two were seriously injured.
During the week of 21 March, residents of Kyelinda village, in Buwenge, stoned 2 men to death. The men were accused of stealing goats.

During the week of 21 March, a group of unidentified men wielding spears and pangas, supported by the police, attacked the residents of Ceke village, in Nwoya. The militia were deployed by a local businessman who is in a land dispute with the villagers. A villager was stabbed in the back, a child ran away, 11 huts were burned, 20 granaries were destroyed, and shops and supplies were looted.

During the week of 18 March, UPDF soldiers came to the house of a man living on a farm in Obira Parish, Got Apwoyo, in Nwoya. They ordered him out of his hut, set the hut on fire, and then beat him until he passed out. The land is wanted by a senior general.
On March 20, in Kampala city (Kampala, Kampala), Inspector General of Police (IGP) Ochola reorganized the command and supervision of all 13 specialized units in the police force.

During March and April 2018, soldiers evicted over 6,000 villagers from their lands in Pakwach district. The soldiers burned down huts, beat the villagers severely, and stole livestock and property. This land has now been occupied by a senior UPDF official. Coded as two events per month with a date precision of 2.

On 18 March, a group of Muslim men wielding pangas attached the Ishaka-Basajjabalaba Mosque protested in Bushenyi. They were repelled by the police, with support from the army. This group is unhappy with the leadership of the district Kadhi.
On 17 March, a group of over 70 people wielding pangas attached the Ishaka-Basajjabalaba Mosque protested in Bushenyi. The police arrested 3 protesters.
On 17 March 2018, the Local Council 5 Chairman of Isingiro organised a militia to launch a counter-attack on a group of tax collectors who had beaten him the previous day.
On 16 March, a group of tax collectors ambushed the Local Council 5 Chairman of Isingiro near Mile 4, along Isingiro. They beat him and damaged his car.

Property destruction: On 16 March, soldiers began an eviction exercise in Apaa. They burned down huts and forced residents to leave. The Ugandan Wildlife Authority has decreed that the 15,000 residents in Apaa must vacate their property.

On 15 March, boda boda riders blocked the Kampala-Gulu highway while protesting against the violence used by police members against several riders. The protest was a direct reaction to the police's intervention the day before, impouding dozens of uninsured motorcycles belonging to boda boda riders. The protest took hours, with rioters pelting stones and police using tear gas and live bullets shot in the air.

Arrests: on 13 March, 40 supporters of the FDC were arrested in Jinja by police, ahead of the Jinja East Constituency by-election scheduled for the next day and while they held a post-campaign evaluation meeting for the FDC candidate, Mr Paul Mwiru. Another report mentions 48 arrests.
On 11 March, a UPDF soldier was killed - Pte Ibrahim Congo - by South Sudanese gunmen in Padiga (Metu), during an operation to recover 836 animals.

On 11 March, rival supporters clashed in Nakabango during the Land Minister Namuganza's visit of Prince Edward Columbus Wambuzi's palace. The pro-Kyabazinga Nadiope/Kadaga supporters wanted to lynch the Minister but were confronted by the pro-Namuganza. Some injuries and arrests reported.

During March and April 2018, soldiers evicted over 6,000 villagers from their lands in Pakwach district. The soldiers burned down huts, beat the villagers severely, and stole livestock and property. This land has now been occupied by a senior UPDF official. Coded as two events per month with a date precision of 2.
On March 9, a UPDF member was lynched in public in Kamwezi Sub County.

Police had to intervene in a protest organised by Kyambogo University students on March 6th, when they protested the postponement of the voting for the student guilds. Police also arrested 2 guild members and an unspecified number of other students.
300 students of the Kabale Institute of Health Science marched in Kabale on March 5 protesting maladministration, mistreatment and poor services at the institute.

On the week of 5 March, youth protested at the Kingdom headquarters in Bugembe, promising not to allow Minister Namuganza to go to Bugosa unless she apologised for her comments on Kyabazinga Wilberforce Gabula Nadiope IV and Speaker Rebecca Kadaga.

On March 2nd, Acholi and Paluo militia clashed at Bedmot village (coordinates for Mutanda sub-county, Kiryandongo, used). Four people were injured (though the source does not specify the identity of the victims), and at least 7 houses were torched. The event represents an escalation in a land dispute, connected to a former Paluo MP.

Unidentified armed men slit a woman's throat in Jinja road, in Bweyongerere, on March 1st. She was taken to the hospital for treatment. Police, who was located nearby, pursued the gunmen and killed two.

Students of Dr Obote College, in Boroboro, went on rampage destroying public property and the head teacher's premises allegedly after the school declined a proposal for a disco after the religious service. According to a student, they were protesting the continued stay of the head teacher Fred Kiwanuka. The event stopped when police used tear gas and bullets to disperse the students.
Arrests: after another round of kidnappings in Kampala, police arrested 27 suspects. 16 were charged under the court of law and 11 are under inquiry.

On February 23rd, the SPLA kidnapped 5 South Sudanese refugees and raided over 200 herds of cattle from Gbari and Arapi villages in Metu. The attack started with the intention to drive the cattle to South Sudan. By then, one of the abducted refugees had already allegedly been killed. 2 others managed to escape while the UPDF's chased the rebels 60km into South Sudan.

Police officers chased and whipped several journalists who were covering the trial of former Buyende DPC Muhammad Kirumira in Kololo, Kampala. Journalists who were covering the event were waiting for them at the location when they were assaulted by police, who beat and punched them, forcing them to flee. These reports of violence are denied by the police.
On Friday February 16, a man was clobbered to death by a mob in Kihihi, due to being accused of stealing 2 chickens.

source: Chimp Reports; Daily Monitor (Uganda); Weekly Observer
notes: On February 15, 2 police officers stationed in Kizza zone, Kawempe Division, were killed by unknown assailants and had their guns stolen.
A 13 year old boy died in Musoni village, Kamet Sub-county, on February 14th, due to the detonation of a grenade.

Human Rights Awareness and Promotion Forum's premises were broken into on February 9th by 9 unidentified armed men who attacked 2 security guards after disabling the security system. The 2 individuals sustained severe injuries.

On February 12, the UDPF laid siege to the Guardian Primary school under the claim that the institution was illegally using their land. Upon being surrounded, the principal called for students and parents to forcefully enter the school. The ensuing situation led to some of the people being injured by the police.

Property destruction: on February 9th, an unidentified group raided the offices of a local NGO at 3am, not stealing anything, but destroying the place. This attack comes in the sequence of a series of mysterious attacks aimed at civil society organisations.
On February 7, in Kampala city (Kampala, Kampala), unidentified actors killed a woman who was an administrator of a prominent local farm for unknown reasons.

On February 5th, mob justice was exerted on a man who was trying to rob a bodaboda motorcycle. The same man is believed to have murdered a police officer last year in Mbarara. Residents of Keihangara Sub County in Ibanda district beat the man to death after he was found with an AK-47, despite having no rounds.
A UPDF officer killed 2 civilians in Arua, Ayivu district, on January 31st, before killing himself.

On January 22nd, the Boda Boda militia raided the offices of the rival group Boda Boda 2010 in different parts of Kampala, where office material was set ablaze (locations include Wakaliga, Katwe, Makindye, Natete, Nsangi and Kyengera among others). The development followed the arrest the day prior of some members of the Boda Boda 2010 militia group, including its leader Abdallah Kitatta, who was held in connection to a murder case.

After arrests of several members of the Boda Boda 2010 militia by the military, and another arrest of one member on Friday 19 January, the members of the militia took to the streets of Kampala to protest. The police used tear gas and live bullets to disperse the crowd, but the members of the militia blocked streets and threatened with more violence if their member was not released.

On 14 January 2018, a Burundian refugee in Nakivale camp in Uganda was attacked by unidentified people. According to him, the sponsors of the attack are from Bujumbura. The perpetrators set his vehicle on fire and his house was hit by flames.

After the Luwero town issued a notice for the relocation of Binyonyi farmers market from Luwero-Kiwoto to Kiyenje, traders did not comply. They set up their market on January 8th, and reportedly pelted the police with stones, In retaliation, the police dispersed them by resorting to tear gas. 3 traders were arrested for inciting violence.

On January 2nd, an unidentified group of armed people attacked the districts of Lwengo (village of Kiryasaaka) and Bukomansimbi (villages of Kisojjo, Kyabagoma and Kyamabaale). 5 people were killed and 12 others were injured. 2 fatalities recorded in Lwengo.

On January 2nd, an unidentified group of armed people attacked the districts of Lwengo (village of Kiryasaaka) and Bukomansimbi (villages of Kisojjo, Kyabagoma and Kyamabaale). 5 people were killed and 12 others were injured. 3 fatalities recorded in Kibinge.

NRM Protesters took to the street in front of the Civil Division of the High Court in Kampala protesting litigations against Parliament Speaker Rebecca Kadaga. The group claims that Kadaga is being targeted over presiding the proceedings that led to the passing of the age limit law. The protesters argued that Kadaga had nothing to answer to in regards to the bill having passed, which they claim happened in the right manner.
A policeman was victim of mob justice on January 1st, in the Makindye Division, in Kampala. The motive for the killing is allegedly that the officer was involved in a motorcycle robbery.

Raid: an unidentified group of 3 armed men attacked the Offices of the Citizens' Coalition for Electoral Democracy in Nsambya, Uganda, on December 26th, with a security guard having his gun taken before the raid. The raid was confirmed by the Office's coordinator, but the reports were rejected and delegitimised by the police.
On December 25th, a group of residents of Odek sub county exercised mob justice on another resident who had stolen a bull. The victim was beaten up and died in the hospital.

A Rwandan refugee was surrounded by RNC members and Mukombozi members in a shopping mall in Ntinda, Kampala, on the week of the 24th of December. He was taken to Katuna border, where he was brought to Kigali and allegedly blindfolded and beaten.
Shots were heard during the day in Busunga because of clashes between the UPDF and ADF, on December 24th.

Non-violent activity: 50 soldiers/presidential police members entered Uganda's Parliament on Monday 18th December when the age limit bill that would allow President Museveni's presidency to continue was being discussed. Several reports mention that soldiers took over the Catholic and Anglican chaplains. The soldiers' presence sparked fears over the security of the MPs, which in turn led to a scuffle on Tuesday morning when the house resumed debating the contentious age limit amendment bill, resulting in the debate being adjourned and restarted two hours later.

actor2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
notes: Agreement: President Museveni allows for a joint military cooperation between Uganda and DRC to fight the insurgent ADF forces.

During a march from Ugandan Democratic Party members in Kampala, on the way to the Parliament, on December 12th, police arrested the party president general - Norbert Mao - and 11 other party members. The group was marching to Parliament to protest against the proposed scrapping of the presidential age limit. The 12 are being held on tentative charges of holding an unlawful procession.

On December 7th, around 40 people took part in a peaceful protest organised by the Pan-African Pyramid, a non-partisan organization who ideal is to revive 'intellectual' discourse on Pan-Africanism. The protesters demonstrated in front of the Lybian embassy against the reports of slave trade in the country, demanding to know whether the reports were true or false, and asking for the government to formally recognise the United Nations High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR) and allow it fully carry out its mandate.

Movement of forces: The government of Uganda increases security at settlements hosting over one million displaced South Sudanese people, after reports that some elements in Sudan People's Liberation Army In the Opposition (SPLA-IO) were trying to recruit rebels to fight the South Sudan government.

Unknown gunmen assassinated on Wednesday 6th South Sudanese MP Jacob Kuwinsuk Gale in the district of Yumbe. The MP was in the company of other people making consultations as part of the national dialogue for South Sudanese refugees in Uganda. No armed group has claimed the attack so far.

source: Chimp Reports; Daily Monitor (Uganda); Red Pepper (Uganda)
notes: On Tuesday 28th the UPDF killed a Turkana pastoralist during a clash in Losilang. The gunfire clash lasted for 20 minutes, and happened after the Turkana had raided cows in Losilang village in Kotido District.

On Tuesday 28th, an angry mob that wanted to lynch a thief in Adjumani district engaged with police killing 3 people. The mob descended on the police and burnt 6 motorcycles at the police post. The three casualties included one student, one resident and one rioter.

Police arrested six district leaders of the Obusinga bwa Rwenzururu in Kasese district. The suspects had started mobilising the residents to assemble at the Rwenzori square to demonstrate. In an attempt to disarm one of the police officers, one of them attacked. In response, the police shot and killed him.

More than 5,000 students in the city of Lira arrested their principal on Monday 27th, for alleged corruption and nepotism. The principal was brought to the Lira central police. Police fired teargas and live bullets in order to disperse the angry students.

On Sunday 26th, students of Ayer Seed Secondary School threw stones at the building, smashing the windows of the administration block, the stores and two classroom blocks. The police were tipped off by administrators who had been called by other students.

actor1: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: Gunmen suspected to be members of the SPLA-IO have beheaded a clinical officer and a boda-boda cyclist on the South Sudan-Uganda border district of Moyo, on the 25th. One of the civilians was South-Sudanese while the other was Ugandan. 2 other civilians sustained injuries.

Striking taxi drivers blocked the convoy of President Museveni on Wednesday 22nd, at the Clock Tower in Kampala, as they demonstrated against monthly taxes that are levied by Kampala Capital City Authority. After about 10 minutes, President Museveni was forced to stop and address them on the matter.

source: Chimp Reports; New Vision (Uganda); Weekly Observer
notes: Raid: on Tuesday 21st, Red Pepper's offices in Namanve were raided by Ugandan police forces. This came one day after Red Pepper published a story alleging that Rwanda believed President Yoweri Museveni was plotting to oust President Paul Kagame (with unnamed sources). The police department on Counter Terrorism ransacked the offices and 8 journalists were arrested. Computers and mobiles were confiscated and the houses of some journalists were searched.

On Monday 20th, a group of people stormed the headquarters of the Central Bank in Kampala and demanded for the arrest and prosecution of the director for regulation and supervision, Ms Justine Bagyenda, before they were dispersed by police. Traffic flow was disrupted momentarily by the group, who held placards with messages such as 'arrest Bagyenda, President Museveni arrest Bagyenda' and tried to force their way into the premises. They fled when police arrived at the scene.

During an anti-cattle raid on Sunday, the UPDF killed a 23 year old student in Katakwi District. The student was mistaken by a cattle hustler. When asked for ID, he ran away and was shot by the soldiers on the head.

On Saturday 18th, the Rubabo County MP Mary Paula Turyahikayo was forced to stop an age consultation meeting after a group of rowdy youth disrupted it. The incident happened at Kayanga Primary School in Kisiizi and the group prevented the MP from continuing her address, forcing her to leave in order to avoid chaos.
Defusal: A bomb was disarmed by the bomb squad and the police, who were called to inverne, at Kampala Jinja Highway on Wendesday 15th.

Police used live bullets and teargas to quell a violent strike by students at Ndorwa Muslim Secondary School in Southern Division in Kabale Municipality. Students started pelting their teachers with stones and destroyed windowpanes in several classrooms.The anti-riot police fired live bullets and used tear gas to disperse the riot.

A protest took place on the 14th, in Mbarara. The group encountered a police road block at the Mbarara-Masaka road junction (Mahembe Gente), and stones started flying and police responded with teargas, water cannons and live bullets. The police at this point decided to arrest Besigye in his Land cruiser, which they pulled to Mbarara police station.

On Monday 13th, protesters demonstrating against the amendments to the Constitution clashed with police in Moyo. Due to poor road infrastructure in the area, tensions had been rising for some time. It emerged that the police had also arrested Obongi County MP Fungaroo Kaps, which enraged his supporters. When police tried to arrest the lawmaker on Monday, protesters clashed with the police officers. The military was sent later to restore order.
During the clashes in Moyo on Monday 13th, rioters attacked an officer of the UNRA, who was later hospitalised.

Armed riot police officers deployed at the venue of a protest fired teargas canisters to disperse a crowd of youth who wore red ribbons as they cheered the opposition politicians who had just arrived at the venue. Police also lobbed tear gas canisters under the cars of the opposition politicians to have them come out of their vehicles and abandon the venue but in vain. Mr. Besigye, who was attending, locked himself in his car, refusing to Mr Wanyama, Aswa Regional Police Commander. The presidential contender was been held static in his car for nearly three hours since 3:00pm by armed riot police officers who also double shielded his car with a police firefighting truck and police patrol pickup. Mr. Besigye managed to escape without being arrested.

Police in Lira district indiscriminately fired tear gas canisters at supporters of former Forum for Democratic Change [FDC] presidential candidate Dr Kizza Besigye, leaving two people seriously injured. It started with the police ordering the protesters to leave the Lira mayor's gardens, after which the protesters disobeyance led the police to start firing tear gas canisters. Police on Thursday apologised to 'innocent' people in Lira town who were affected by the tear gas and rowdy Tuesday atmosphere. One person was shot by a stray bullet.

Police fired live bullets and teargas to disperse supporters of the opposition figure who had gathered at Arrow Square in Soroti. Police also arrested former Presidential candidate Dr Kizza Besigye, who led a group of Forum for Democratic Change leaders to a campaign rally in the municipality. Besigye, who was in company of the FDC Presidential candidate Patrick Amuriat Oboi was arrested as the situation worsened and detained at Soroti Police station. The police also mentioned that they dispersed the raly because it was taking place illegally. According to the Daily Nation, supporters of Besigye engaged with police in battle for almost 6hours. Some people were injured and others hospitalised.

Police in Kabale on Sunday afternoon dispersed a group of students from Kanungu district (The Kanungu Kabale Students Association (KAKASA)) that had convened to protest the way Dr. Chris Baryomunsi, the Kinkiizi East legislator has been conducting his consultations on the proposed amendment of Presidential age limit.

Police in Mbale Town under the command of the District Police Commander fired live bullets and teargas to disperse the opposition leaders and supporters who had gathered at scene to welcome FDC presidential candidate, Patrick Amuriat Oboi. The police also arrested Mr. Amuriat Oboi on allegations of holding an illegal assembly and inciting violence. He was injured during the arrest. Pressure was also created by FDC leaders who camped outside the police station demanding his immediate release. During the arrest, some police officers were seen kicking Mr Amuriat who was already on ground helpless.

State Minister, Hajj Abdul Nadduli, faced an angry crowd in Mikono during the weekend. He was meeting NRM leaders from the districts of Buvuma, Mukono, Buikwe and Kayunga on the invitation of Sam Bbemba, a party member. The attendants to the meeting became rowdy and denounced the age limit Bill after they were denied allowances. The protesters entered the house and tried to burn files and party cards before the anti-riot police stopped them.
After Okello Tango was hit in the head, police was forced to intervene with live bullets and teargas.

The Member of Parliament for Kioga County in Amolatar district, Anthony Okello Tango was on Saturday afternoon stoned on the head with a brick by youths against the controversial presidential age limit. The youths demanded to know whether he was in support of the age limit bill. He was also questioned about the 29 million given to each MP to consult on the age limit bill. All MPs not supporting the Bill have been returning the money Okello Tango had not.

300 residents from the Rubaare Town held a protest, accusing their legislator, Deputy Attorney General Mwesigwa Rukutana, of locking them out of the age limit consultative meeting. As 220 NRM members convened in Rubaare to discuss the amendment, they were blocked from entering the meeting and participating in the vote. With red bandanas tied around their heads, the demonstrators, who included youth and women, took to the streets.

Students started a riot, turning on each other, over the dispute of 2 male students who were competing for a girl who had recently moved to the school. The situation got out of control and turned out, with one house being vandalised.
The anti-riot police had to be called to put an end to the situation. They eventually fired teargas and rubber bullets to contain it.

An angry mob raids the home of John Peter Ematu, the North Kyoga regional police commander, accusing him of brutalising MPs while pelting his house with stones. This event came after police used teargas as real bullets to disperse a consultative meeting on the presidential age limit organised by the Lira Woman MP.

Protesters angered at Besingye's re-arrest protest outside the police station in Rukungiri. Police used tear gas in order to disperse the crowd. Eyewitnesses confirm that two aides of Mr. Besingye were beaten.

Arrests: Uganda's opposition leader, Kizza Besigye, was re-arrested just 5 hours after being released from spending 6 days in detention and charged with inciting violence. The motives for the new arrest are not clear. Reports mention that it might be an attempt to circumvent the long stay in detention by the Government.

Protesters were out in the streets to demontrate against the proposal bill for increasing the age limit of presidential candidates. When MP Joy Atim was making her speech, other MPs joined the gathering. At this point, police became violent. After the police became violent, the protesters started turning on the police and pelting stones at them.
Multiplex company workers are protesting over poor conditions. They are demanding higher pay and better conditions.

Opposition protesters belonging to the FDS storm the police office of Nagalama to demand the release of the party's former president - Dr. Kizza Besingye - and other party leaders who have been held there for days without a trial.

The protest against the constitutional ammendment for the age limit of the candidates for the presidentials was called by Mbale Municipality MP Jack Wamanga and went peacefully from the start at 3pm until 4pm. Then, the opposition leader Winfred Kiiza arrived. At the interval, police ordered protesters to stop the demonstration since meetings attended by politicians and officers from other constituencies were banned. The police started firing bullets and tear-gas at protesters when the crowd did not disperse.
Police teargassed angry youths who stormed Jinja East Municipality MP Mr Nathan Igeme Nabeta's home with the aim of setting it on fire on.

Protest in Mbale Town against the Constitutional Amendment that seeks among others to remove presidential age limits from the 1995 Constitution. Police fired teargas and live bullets to disperse the protestors. Secretary General for Forum for Democratic Change (FDC) was arrested.

On 20 October, angry residents of Nyabubaare Sub-county protested and closed the 15km road connecting Ishaka town through Kizinda trading center to areas of Bitereko in Mitooma District saying the road is impassable, making it hard for them to transact business and find safe way to their destinations.
In Kyengera town in Busiro East constituency, bullets and tear gas were reported during an age limit consultative meeting.

Police fired tear gas and live bullets to disperse protesters opposed to the amendment of the constitution to remove the age limit cap at Nateete, Rubaga South in Kampala. Stick-wielding goons were also seen working with police officers.
Arrests: FDC's Col. Dr Kizza Besigye was arrested on 19 October at Burambira Trading Center in Bubaare Sub County, Rubanda district by waiting police as he tried to enter Kabale.
Ugandan police banned what it termed illegal demonstrations over plans to remove presidential age limits, seen as paving the way for President Yoweri Museveni to serve a sixth term in office.
Two people were taken to hospital after police used teargas and live bullets to dispersed a consultative rally on age limit in Kasubi, Rubaga Division, in Kampala.

Police shot dead between one and two people at a political rally. Police blocked hundreds of opposition supporters from entering a stadium in Rukungiri on 18 October. During the standoff, some opposition supporters pelted police with stones.

On 17 October, Ugandan police fired teargas and rubber bullets at opposition supporters in Kasubi, Rubaga Division, in Kampala protesting plans to remove presidential age limits. Two people were rushed to hospital.

Students of Kigezi High School burnt down a dormitory on 16 October. They were protesting the expulsion of two of their colleagues. Police came in and managed to disperse the students with bullets and teargas.
On 16 October, rallies were held at Kalerwe and Bwaise against a proposed presidential age limit removal.
On 16 October, rallies were held at Kalerwe and Bwaise against a proposed presidential age limit removal.
Hoima residents have lynched a suspected robber.

Clashes between security officers from Uganda People's Defence Forces and police: officials from Internal Security Organisation (ISO) blocked police from arresting a former girlfriend of killed Assistant Inspector General of Police leading to the clash.
Students burned down a dormitory block in Standard College, Ntungamo.
On 10 Octoer, DP and NRM supporters clashed over the presidential term limit in Lwengo.
Dickson Wasswa was severely beaten by security officers who residents claim were deployed by the minister to guard his land and to evict them from 'his' land.

Unknown assailants attacked four villages, injured seven people and burnt one of their homes in Kalungu District on Friday morning. Assailants descended on villages of Kalungi in Lukaya Town Council, Bugiri, Kisimbanyiriri and Lusango in Bukulula Sub County.

Unknown assailants attacked four villages, injured seven people and burnt one of their homes in Kalungu District on Friday morning. Assailants descended on villages of Kalungi in Lukaya Town Council, Bugiri, Kisimbanyiriri and Lusango in Bukulula Sub County.

Unknown assailants attacked four villages, injured seven people and burnt one of their homes in Kalungu District on Friday morning. Assailants descended on villages of Kalungi in Lukaya Town Council, Bugiri, Kisimbanyiriri and Lusango in Bukulula Sub County.
Two grenades were hurled by unknown assailants at the residences of MP Allan Ssewanyana (Makindye East) and MP Robert Kyagulanyi alias Bobi Wine (Kyadondo East) at about 1am Tuesday night.
MP Bobi Wine - Robert Kyagulanyi declared that two granades hit his house on October, 1st. No injuries reported.
Two explosives ripped through the house of Rubaga North MP Moses Kasibante. No casualties reported.
University of Makerere students protested against the anti age bill, lighting fires to block roads. At least 13 students were arrested.
24 people were arrested in Ankole and Teso sub regions for holding unlawful assemblies to protest the anti age limit bill.
24 people were arrested in Ankole and Teso sub regions for holding unlawful assemblies to protest the anti age limit bill.

Security operatives forced some legislators out of the Chambers as they refused to leave the room to protest their suspension after disagreements over the debate to lift the presidential age limit of 75 years.
Anti age limi protests in Mukono. An unidentified police officer undressed the Municipal speaker as they tried to arrest her for participating in the protests.
Police dispersed a demonstration against the anti age bill in Kabale university.

Age limit protests spread to Arua, Mbarara, Masaka. Police fired bullets, teargas to disperse hundreds of youths who have taken onto the streets over the age limit. Several arrests were made. Protesters reportedly blocked streets, burned disused vehicle tyres and brandished placards with messages denouncing the move to lift the age cap.

Age limit protests spread to Arua, Mbarara, Masaka. Police fired bullets, teargas to disperse hundreds of youths who have taken onto the streets over the age limit. Several arrests were made. The police engaged the protesters in running battles on Kumi, Republic and Bishop Wasikye roads as they pelted stones at the anti-riot officers.
Police in Masaka District arrested six members of Forum for Democratic Change (FDC), who staged a march to protest the impending removal of the presidential age limit from the Constitution.

Business paralysed in Mbarara town as police battled with Forum for Democratic Change's secretary for mobilization Ingrid Turinawe and the party presidential candidate Amuriat Patrick Oboi who led a procession against lifting of the presidential age limit. After ten minutes the crowd started pelting stones at police which prompted them to fire teargas to disperse them.
People protested against the anti age bill in Mbale. Several arrested by police.

Kamuli Municipality was on Monday rocked by gunfire for over three hours as police battled anti-age limit protesters led by opposition Democratic Party [DP] National Youth Chairman Moses Bigirwa. Police intervened to disperse anti-age limit protesters loyal to the Democratic Party (DP) in Kumuli.

Students protesting new academic rules surrounded the Vice Chancellor Prof. Celestine Obua's office. Some students however snuck through the neighboring regional referral hospital gates and poured onto the main road which forced police to unleash teargas.
Over 100 residents of Kahunyira Cell, Rwamucucu Sub County in Rukiga district stormed offices of the Kabale District State Attorney, protesting the release of people who had been arrested for murder.
Police have fired bullets and tear gas to disperse students who have gone on strike demanding the immediate release of their colleagues who are currently detained at Wandageya Police Station.

Residents of Kabonera Town on Thursday blocked Masaka -Mutukula -Bukoba highway protesting the release of suspects in a recent attack which left two people dead and three others injured. The angry residents burnt old tyres in the middle of the road thus paralyzing traffic for several hours. Police from Masaka Central Police Station fired live bullets to disperse the protesters.
In the northern town of Lira, demonstrators left a mock coffin at a central road junction with 'The removal of the presidential age limit is the death of our country' painted on the side.

Hundreds of students at the country's main Makerere University in Kampala waved branches and chanted 'K'ogikwatako!' -- meaning 'Don't dare touch it!' in the local Luganda language -- in reference to the constitutional clause on age limits. Armed officers -- including military police -- fired volleys of teargas forcing the students to flee to their residence halls and hostels.
Police fired tear gas to disperse protestors and arrested opposition politicians who protested the age limit bill in Kampala.
On Wednesday, police issued an order banning protests in Uganda. Ugandan police also raided the offices of a charity and a think tank which have publicly opposed the constitutional change
Ugandan police have detained a lawmaker and 10 others who were arrested while protesting against a plan that they charge would enable the country's long-term president to rule for life.

Another police officer has died after being stabbed and his gun taken by suspected thugs in Busia District. Constable Daniel Mayende was attacked on Sunday night at Kayembe Check Point in Sofia village in Busia Town located Uganda -Kenya border while on night duty.
A guard shot a reveler dead at Kiira Bar in Kamapala.

actor1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
notes: One person has been confirmed dead after an armed group attacked Ugandan fishermen on Lake Albert in western Uganda. According to witnesses, the group invaded the fishermen on Nsonga Landing Site, in Kyangwali sub-county. They allegedly stole mobile phones, boat engines and fish valued at millions of shillings. The attackers were dressed in military uniforms similar to those of Democratic Republic of Congo soldiers.
Thugs raided Mponye police post in Kabalagala Division and hacked a police officer who was on duty and stole his gun.
On Saturday, two Special Police Constables (SPC) attached to Mutundwe police station were killed by thugs moving on motorcycles at Denovo Bread Company in Kalerwe, Kawempe Division in Kampala.
Five panga-wielding men attacked the police post with the view of stealing weapons and injured a constable who was on guard inside the post.
14 September. An activist was shot and severely wounded by armed guards believed to work for the company Ferdsult Engineering Services Limited in Fort Portal.

Arrests: Police and the UPDF in Mbarara on Thursday arrested the region's Democratic Party Vice President Imam Makumbi, while he prepared to launch a procession in protest of Tuesday's adaptation of the age limit removal bill by NRM MPs.
Conductors subscribing to the Kampala Operational Taxi Stages Association (KOTSA) matched on the streets of Kampala supporting the move to uplift the age limit.

Violence erupted n Busei, Iganga District when supporters of a Forum for Democratic Change (FDC) candidate were attacked by thugs affilaited with NRM who were armed with pangas and sticks, leaving them with several wounds.
Police in Budaka District on Monday arrested three Members of Parliament who reportedly staged a demonstration over the sorry state of Mbale-Tirinyi-Nakalama road.
A Makerere University student is arrested following an anti-age limit protest during a presidential speech.
Members of the DP raided Bukerere village in Kalungu town council and began assaulting voters. Several of the suspected assailants were later arrested.
About 20 soldiers beat up people at night on the eve of voting day, but residents doubted whether they were real soldiers.
NRM supporters hold demonstration in Kabale town to support removal of presidential age limit.

Traders shut down their shops in protest against Kampala Capital City Authority-KCCA for allegedly selling off the market to unidentified investor. Carrying placards, the angry vendors poured into the main road. Anti- riot police had to fire bullets and teargas to disperse them.
A Christian group protests against homosexuality in Kampala on 26/08. Details limited.
NRM supporters hold demonstration in Lira to support removal of presidential age limit
Police officers at Katwe Police Station have stoned five journalists who were covering staff quarters that had caught fire at the police station.

Residents in Kasawo village, Buwama sub-county clashed with war veterans over the ownership of the contested land on Block 360 in Bunjakko. Police fired live bullets in the air and used tear-gas to disperse a group of more than 500 residents who engaged in fist fights with a group of veterans they accused of destroying their crops on land. More than 20 people have been hospitalised to several health units.

Ruling party supporters took to the streets of Soroti Town demanding that Members of Parliament drop the proposed Constitutional amendment and instead amend the Constitution to allow Ugandans above 75 to contest for presidency.
Looting: soldiers looting miners' goods during their eviction from mines.

A member of the Kirumiramutima, an armed group loyal to the King of Rwenzururu, was shot by army officers: Matayo Bwanzire was held responsible of Mbarage ambush. Bwanzire attempted to fight when army officers ordered him to come out of his house.
Taxi drivers plying the Masaka- Kampala route have parked their vehicles to protest what they termed as illegal taxes being levied on their vehicles by local authorities.
Ibanda school is closed down after students destroyed school properties while proesting the quantity and quality of meals

2 UPDF soldiers are suspected to have beaten to death a civilian in Mutungo, a suburb of Kampala. The two soldiers beat the man after accusing him of theft of a bag of cement from a construction site they were guarding.

A number of Amuru residents were arrested and flogged during an impromptu security crackdown in Kololo parish. Police and soldiers allegedly assaulted civilians in areas where the government wants to forcibly survey 10,000 hectares of arable land for Madhvani Group to set up a sugarcane plantation and sugar factory.
Work was paraylsed at Nakaseke Hospital after residents of Nongo village; Kyikamuli Sub-county Nakaseke stormed the facility, seeking answers over the death of a prisoner.
Police in Soroti district blocked a demonstration by a group of youths protesting the proposed amendment of Article 26 of the Constitution

Demonstrations took place reportedly organised by minister Amongi and MPs Odonga Otto, Lucy Akello, Lucy Aciro and Olanya. Gunshots and tear gas were fired to disperse the protestors and MP Otto was taken into police custody.

actor1: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Prison Guards
notes: Prison wardens are accused of torturing a man to death. The man was remanded in Wakyato prison for allegedly stealing a bodaboda motorcycle but died on Sunday and the body was found with severe wounds. Residents say the wounds on the deceased's body show that he was badly tortured.

Vendors in Kamapala marched to the Kampala Capital City Authority (KCCA), carrying a dead body of a trader who drowned while escaping KCCA law enforcement. As the angry crowd attempted to force its way into the KCCA offices, police fired live bullets and confronted them to disperse them and recover the body.
An elder and Councilor of Bwisumbo Sub County was ambushed and stabbed to near death by unknown assailants. He identified the attackers as Matayo Bwanzire and Kule Mawano.
