Arrests: Police allegedly raided presidential candidate Amama Mbabazis campaign offices in Nakasero and his home in Kololo. At least 25 of his supporters were arrested and taken to unknown locations without explanation.
Arrests: Police arrested the Kibanda Sub county NRM party chairperson in Rakai district over cattle theft.

As Mr Mbabazi led a procession through Ntungamo town, a group of NRM enthusiasts lined along the road provoking Mbabazis team. A stone was thrown at Mbabazis security vehicle, which sparked battles between the two camps. Several people were injured
At Kitwe in Ruhaama constituency Mbabazis supporters vandalised a car pasted with Musevenis campaign posters. Its occupants who were allegedly commanding anti-Mbabazi protesters fled for their life

Over 50 angry NRM members stormed Zebra Hotel Gardens at the launch of Musevenis campaigns, and threatened to lynch minister Ssempijja for sponsoring his daughter against the official party candidate.
Luweero Residents Protest Budget Cuts to Water Sector
Traders Protest Delayed Mambule Road Works

FDC candidate for Nakaseke North MP, Ivan Masembe disappeared on 3rd December in Luwero, shortly after being nominated. He was discovered 6 days later. FDC chairperson for Nakaseke district, Sseguya Matovu insists Masembe has been under captivity for political reasons.
A deceaseds family members and residents stormed the Buyamba police post calling for action against his suspect murderer.

Kitgum Woman MP Beatrice Anywar came under attack from a section of FDC supporters who attempted to block her from accessing a campaign rally podium at Kitgum. Anywar abandoned FDC and seconded the presidential nomination of Mbabazi last month
Mbale Residents Protest Against UNRA over road
Suspected supporters of Iganga Woman NRM MP contestant Hilat Magumba allegedly attempted to kidnap Iganga NRM Registrar Kirunda
Chaos erupted as angry Mbabazi supporters accused his mobilization team of holding money for their fuel and lunch facilitation.

NRM supporters and Amama Mbabazis supporters face off in Mbarara town. Mbabazis supporters accuse Museveni supporters of tearing down his postsers. There are reports of scuffles but no serious violence or clashes. One person has been arrested and detained at Mbarara police in connection with the act.
Dozens of musicians stormed the ruling NRM party headquarters demanding for payment for the songs that they composed for President Museveni ahead of his campaign for a fifth term in office.
NRM Candidates fought at a meeting in Moroto district organised to resolve disputes arising from the party primaries.
At least 23 people were assaulted and 15 houses destroyed during Kaliro NRM Election Violence. Five people were arrested in connection with the violence
Peaceful demonstration by women activists in Fort Portal town against a lower court verdict in a domestic violence case

More than 100 residents of Pawel-Adak village, Patiko Sub-county in Gulu District, are homeless after their houses were burnt in an attack by residents from Amuru District following the death of a boda boda cyclist. Police used teargas to disperse the group that also invaded the station where the suspect was held.

Kampala Mayor Erias Lukwago was temporarily detained as he proceeded to the Electoral Commission offices to demonstrate against the delayed nominations and failure for EC to give him official communication on the matter.

source: Human Rights Network for Journalists Uganda
notes: Police fired teargas, rubber and live bullets to disperse Lukwagos supporters who were opposed to a move by police to block him from walking to the Electoral Commission headquarters in Kampala to return his Mayoral nominations papers

source: Human Rights Network for Journalists Uganda
notes: 2 journalists were shot in the head by police while covering the arrest of Capital Citys Lord Mayor, Erias Lukwago. The two journalists are alive but in critical condition.
Clashes between NRM rival candidates over vote rigging at Kitovu polling station. Police intervened to stop the clash

Presidential candidate, Joseph Elton Mabirizi was allegedly kidnapped by six armed men who dumped him in Namasoga bush in Iganga the following day. Police was forced to shoot in the air to disperse a group of people who wanted to block them from taking Mabirizi

Presidential candidate, Joseph Elton Mabirizi was allegedly kidnapped by six armed men who dumped him in Namasoga bush in Iganga the following day. Police was forced to shoot in the air to disperse a group of people who wanted to block them from taking Mabirizi
Supporters Fight Before Museveni Over alleged vote rigging during NRM Primaries
Physical confrontation ensued at the Kitgum district FDC offices when the planned primary elections turned chaotic, leading into tearing and burning of the party register and ballot papers
Youth supporters of Mbabazi were attacked and beaten by unidentified attackers at Bukulula village in Mukungwe Sub-county in Masaka District
Go Forward Youth chairperson is nursing wounds after unidentified people attacked him and beat him up before setting his car on fire over his support to presidential candidate Mbabazi
After a suspected arsonist escapes the police, community members find and fatally lynch the suspect.
Christians at Kitanga Catholic parish in Kabale district staged a peaceful demonstration against police brutality and failure by government to offer quality services to citizens
FDC delegates traded blows and assaulted each other at the parties primaries for members of parliament and local councils in Mbale, amid suspicion that the ruling NRM party had infiltrated them.
Police fired tear gas at NRM party supporters in Kisiita sub-county, Kibaale district who were protesting results of the recent primaries.

Angry Democratic Party Members from Mukono South Constituency led by their Chairperson have stormed the party HQ at City House in Kampala, accusing the party Executive Committee for halting party primaries in favor of one candidate.

Anti-riot police in Kabarole has been engaged in running battles with angry protesting supporters of NRM elections loser, John Busingye. The supporters stormed Kasenda trading center in Kasenda sub county, destroyed and damaged Katanda Bridge which connects Rutete and Kasenda sub counties, and blocked traffic prompting a team of anti-riot police to intervene. Police with the help of the army fired teargas and live bullets to disperse the protesters.

A journalist was reportedly shot in the head while covering an incident of vote rigging during NRM party elections at Bulera police station in the Mityana district. Two unidentified men have so far been arrested and detained. The scuffle ensued when an unidentified man turned up at a polling station near the police with ballot papers, and could not explain where he got them. The local people became hostile and wanted to lynch him, but he managed to escape and hid inside the police station. His car was broken into, and the ballot papers were scattered by angry locals.
NRM parliamentary aspirant Eddy Ssansa allegedly assaulted a female journalist at Masaka police station on 28 October
In Kamuli, there were reports of scuffles in Buzaaya county and Bugabula between NRM supporters; at least two people were injured

There were at least 10 arrests and many injured in the sub-region that comprises Masaka, Lwengo and Sembabule after fights broke out between NRM supporters over alleged vote rigging during the NRM primary elections. Police forces, supported by the army, intervened to disperse the protesters.

There were at least 10 arrests and many injured in the sub-region that comprises Masaka, Lwengo and Sembabule after fights broke out between NRM supporters over alleged vote rigging during the NRM primary elections. Police forces, supported by the army, intervened to disperse the protesters.

There were at least 10 arrests and many injured in the sub-region that comprises Masaka, Lwengo and Sembabule after fights broke out between NRM supporters over alleged vote rigging during the NRM primary elections. Police forces, supported by the army, intervened to disperse the protesters.

There were at least 10 arrests and many injured in the sub-region that comprises Masaka, Lwengo and Sembabule after fights broke out between NRM supporters over alleged vote rigging during the NRM primary elections. Police forces, supported by the army, intervened to disperse the protesters.

At least 10 arrests and many injured in the sub-region that comprises Masaka, Lwengo and Sembabule after fights broke out between NRM supporters over alleged vote rigging during the NRM primary elections. Police forces, supported by the army, intervened to disperse the protesters. In Lwengo, at least 30 people were injured in the clashes; the head of the political crimes desk was arrested after he was found in possession of pre-ticked ballot papers. LC-V chairman Mutabazi was also arrested.

At least 10 arrests and many injured in the sub-region that comprises Masaka, Lwengo and Sembabule after fights broke out between NRM supporters over alleged vote rigging during the NRM primary elections. Police forces, supported by the army, intervened to disperse the protesters. In Lwengo, at least 30 people were injured in the clashes; the head of the political crimes desk was arrested after he was found in possession of pre-ticked ballot papers. LC-V chairman Mutabazi was also arrested.
A journalist was assaulted and sustained injuries while covering a story in which a police officer was implicated in vote rigging prior the NRM party elections.

Buyaga West NRM incumbent Barnabas Tinkasimire was arrested and briefly detained at Muhoro police station after he stormed a meeting between his rival and police officers ahead of the elections. He accused police of taking sides.
Arrests: Police arrested Dan Ibaale, an aspiring NRM candidate for the Bugweri parliamentary seat on allegations that he was distributing money. He was released the following day.
Angry mob attacked deputy attorney general Mwesigwa Rukutana and city businessman Bob Kabonero during a rally of his opponent to the Rushenyi county NRM flag, Justus Karuhanga
Hoima campaign violence suspects were released after Dr. Lawrence Bategekas supporters stormed the police demanding their release.
The last joint rally for NRM aspirants for the Masaka Local Council Chairman position was forced to end prematurely after fights broke out.
Police have had to fire tear gas and live bullets while enforcing an attached property order in Gulu town.

Two people have been critically injured in elections violence in Hoima during clashes between supporters of minister Henry Muganwa Kajura, the incumbent MP and those of his rival Dr Lawrence Bategeka.
At least 15 people were injured in clashes between rival NRM supporters of West Budama South MP Jacob Oboth-Oboth and Lazarus Oketch at Pawang trading centre in Tororo district
Ntungamo Residents Protest Destruction of Their Property

Mbarara FDC chairman, Stanley Katembeya allegedly mobilised local FDC supporters to protest against this week's pre-emptive arrest of Dr Kizza Besigye. FDC supporters used big stones and smouldering car tyres to block traffic along Mbarara -Masaka highway, Kabale-Mbarara and Bushenyi-Mbarara roads. An electricity transformer in Nyamityobora-Kakoba was also torched, cutting off power supply to the neighbouring areas.

On 16 October, 900 miners at Krone Uganda Mine in Kaara Village in Muko Sub-County, rioted. The miners barricaded the road and set the company buildings ablaze. The police used live bullets to disperse the protesters.
Protesting vote rigging and other electoral malpractices, angry NRM supporters in Masaka District urinated on party T-shirts and burnt membership cards.

Protesting vote rigging and other electoral malpractices, angry NRM supporters in Masaka District urinated on party T-shirts and burnt membership cards; party offices in Ssembabule and Isingiro districts were set ablaze and police officers held captive for hours.
Two NRM supporters were reportedly hacked to death by supporters of a rival candidate

Protesting vote rigging and other electoral malpractices, angry NRM supporters in Masaka District urinated on party T-shirts and burnt membership cards; party offices in Ssembabule and Isingiro districts were set ablaze and police officers held captive for hours. 12 people in Ssembabule district are being detained by police
Arrests: Uganda Police arrested key figures in the FDC (Besigye and Nganda) in Kisangati and Bweyogerere leading to the cancellation of the FDC mobilization tour in Kireka, Mukono, Jinja and Iganga.
Arrests: Uganda Police arrested key figures in the FDC (Besigye and Nganda) in Kisangati and Bweyogerere leading to the cancellation of the FDC mobilization tour in Kireka, Mukono, Jinja and Iganga.
At least three journalists were arrested by police forces at Kira road police station for reporting on FDCs Ssemujjus arrest. Police reportedly used violence on journalists.
In Kampala, an NRM aspirant nearly beat up Dr Tanga Odoi, the chairman of NRM electoral commission, whom he accused of being responsible for the chaos in NRM primaries.
A group of supporters of Salim Uhuru, an aspirant for the Kampala Central LC-III chair, stormed NRMs EC offices on Kyadondo road and demanded a recount of the votes in the Monday elections.

Angry voters throwing pelting NRM party cards after disagreeing with NRM party officials. NRM Officials Rush to at Endinzi sub county headquarters in Isingiro district Bukanga County to Calm Down Angry Voters

Joseph Ssekasamba, the Deputy Masaka RDC raided Masaka NRM offices and stopped the registrar from declaring the results on 12 October. He accused Ssempijja of being a supporter of Mbabazi, who is eyeing the presidency in next years election. This angered Ssempijja and his supporters, whom raided the NRM party offices and threatened to set it on fire
One critically injured during clashes between the supporters of Henry Nswemu, the incumbent Semuto Sub county LC III chairperson and his rival Ismail Kasozi.

assoc_actor_2: FDC: Forum for Democratic Change; Women (Uganda)
notes: Police intercepted four FDC, including a female party official, on the Masaka Mbarara highway, to hold them from proceeding with a rally in Rukungiri district that was not permitted. The aftermath was a number of seriously damaged cars, gunshot wounds and pictures of a woman stripped naked by police officers during the arrest.
LC1 chairpersons house in Amudat District was last week set ablaze by unidentified militants

At least 40 Makerere University students have been arrested over strike. At least one person was injured linked to the use of pepper spray as students fought running battles with police. Students are protesting against the administrations 100 per cent tuition policy.

At least 60 of the 93 families that are awaiting resettlement from land earmarked for an oil refinery staged a peaceful demonstration in Hoima town, protesting governments failure to relocate them three years after acquiring their land.
Chaos erupted at Kitgum following the absence of a voters register. The registrar and party administrator had to escape by motor cycles after party members turned rowdy.

Violent strike at Kyambogo university where students' concerns ranged from high surcharge fees, few seats in the lecture theatre, poor lighting at the university to poor sanitation and hygiene. What started as a peaceful sit down strike later turned violent when some students started throwing stones and damage material .

Violent student strike on 3 October after the school administration declined to extend the candidates farewell party to 10pm from 6.00pm. damages and destruction were reported during the strike and 15 students were arrested. 700 students were temporary suspended from school and requested to pay a fine
A Nsangi political aspirant was severely injured by unknown assailants who dumpted him in Masaka
Moroto Aspirant Raphael Eritoi was attacked along Moroto-Kitale road and shot twice in the chest while on his way home.
Damage caused at riot by residents during protests against the interdiction of Doctor Joseph Bill Otuko at Budadiri Health Center
Police is investigating circumstances under which a businessman was shot dead, and two others including a parish NRM chairperson were injured by unknown assailants.

Police on Thursday clashed with residents of Budadiri Town Council in Sironko District protesting against the transfer of Dr Joseph Otuke, the in-charge of Budadiri Heath Centre IV, by the district authorities. One person was injured in the fraca. When police intervened, the residents turned rowdy, set ablaze two staff houses and a drug store. Police used teargas and bullets to disperse them.
Police teargased Idah Nantaba, the minister of state for Lands and her supporters after they complained of rigging during the NRM elections
NRM elections in Luweero look set to be violent as supporters of various candidates engaged in fights on the first day of campaigns
Tabliq faithful gathered in hundreds in protest against Constitutional Court Judge Eldad Mwangusya declination to release nine jailed Muslim leaders including the leader of Tabliqs sect Yunus Kamoga

Police fired live bullets in the air to disperse supporters of Muhammed Muyanja Mbabaali lost his position of NRM district chairperson to Mulindwa Birimumaaso and that a polling agent had allegedly put pre-ticked papers in the ballot box.
Susan Kataike, the minister of state for Luweero Triangle and Woman MP, had to be rescued by police from a mob that wanted to lynch her linked to NRM elections. Kataike escaped without injury.

NRM members expressed their discontent with the Jinja district NRM administrative secretary and police who they accused of engaging in malpractices. Protesting youths rolled in the mud, drunk muddy water or tore NRM party membership cards.
NRM members clashed during elections due to alleged irregularities and disagreements among supporters of various candidates.
Chaos broke out as candidates ferried supporters to impersonate genuine voters and vote for them, leading to a clash between rival camps.
NRM meeting ends up in fight. One NRM aspirant was injured.

Police fired rubber bullets and tear gas to block surging crowds accompanying presidential aspirant Amama Mbabazi in Jinja. Residents hurled stones and sticks at the police. at least one man was shot and three injured. The police later denied any shooting or injury

20 people were injured - including four critically (three police officers) - following running battles between police and crowds attending Amama Mbabazis rally in Soroti. The residents managed to cut off a team of about 30 Police officers at Soroti Sports Grounds and threatened to lynch them; they also cut off Serere road. Police reportedly fired teargas and held 15 Mbabazi activists for defacing Musevenis posters. The police warned presidential aspirants against holding campaign rallies instead of consultative meetings.
Protests erupted after the nullification of NRM primary election polls in Morto; police deployed at the Moroto movement offices .
Hundreds of Voters stormed Kabale NRM Party Offices Over Irregularities in the parties primary elections (inflated vote registers vs. Spending questions)

Acholi MPs and LCV Chairperson camped at a police station in Pabo sub-county over MP Olanyas detention. Olanya was detained on allegations of inciting violence in the Apaa contested land between Amuru and Adjumani districts. He was released on bail on 10 September
Five people were shot and seriously injured as security forces battled angry protesters over a land dispute between Amuru and Adjumani districts
Motorists protested to denounce poor tarmacked road, despites recent repair.
Protest to denounce funding cuts for health facilities.
During a meeting of FDC, Muntus supporters clashed with Police forces, after complaining that Besigyes posters have been displayed (whereas the Electoral Commission forbids it).
Residents burnt tyres and erected barricades in Bukwo. Police commander used his weapon.
Hundreds of people demonstrated in Kitgum streets on the International Day of the Disappeared, to remember people abducted by the LRA.
Democratic Party members protested outcome of grass root elections in Masaka.
Makerere students protest new policies on sexual morality, alcohol and gambling.
Protests against the destruction of crops.
Property owners affected by expansion of Mbarara-Kikagati-Murongo bridge protest delayed compensation by road authorities.
Youths from NRM demonstrate against former PM Mbabazi.
Protesters outside of the regional passport office demand the return of 9 people from Uttarakhand, India, that have suppoesdly been trafficked in Kampala.

Youth calling themselves NRM 24/7 gather in front of former Prime Minister Mbabazis (NRM) home with banners demanding promised jobs. Another group of youths emerged from the house and threw stones and canes. The two groups fought outside the home. No injuries reported.

assoc_actor_2: Shiite Muslim Group (Uganda); Police Forces of Uganda (1986-)
notes: Shiite and Tabliq Muslim groups fought at the court in Jinja during the trial of ADF members. Police fired tear gas and live bullets to disperse the rioters.
Shiite Muslims protest outside Jinja Central police Station, demanding the release of members arrested during riots at the courthouse earlier in the day.
Protests against the merger of two sub-counties in Namutumba District. Police fired tear gas and bullets to disperse crowds.
Another attack was led by South Sudanese army, after trying to invade Ugandas Lamwo District last Friday. Military Forces of Uganda repelled the attack. No casualties announced.
Students riot because teachers refused to expel gay students. Police intervened and fired tear gas.

Arrests: Following an attempt to murder an Imam the day before, 16 police officer were arrested on Tuesday. These officers were supposed to ensure Imam's security, after several other imams have been killed over the last months in Uganda.

On Friday, troops of the South Sudanese army (between 200 and 300 soldiers) enter 9km into Uganda in Lamwo district. More than 400 Ugandan were displaced. Military forces of Uganda launched an assault against the South Sudanese, who fled, leaving motorbikes and South Sudanese flags. No casualties announced.
Anti-corruption protests were held when Minister Byandala was welcomed in Luweero.

Strike:At least 6 universities (Mbarara, Kyambogo, Busitema, Gulu, Muni (Arua) and Makerere) were shut down on Monday while non-teaching staff engaged in a strike due to budget issues. Police forces were deployed.

Strike:At least 6 universities (Mbarara, Kyambogo, Busitema, Gulu, Muni (Arua) and Makerere) were shut down on Monday while non-teaching staff engaged in a strike due to budget issues. Police forces were deployed.

Strike:At least 6 universities (Mbarara, Kyambogo, Busitema, Gulu, Muni (Arua) and Makerere) were shut down on Monday while non-teaching staff engaged in a strike due to budget issues. Police forces were deployed.

Strike:At least 6 universities (Mbarara, Kyambogo, Busitema, Gulu, Muni (Arua) and Makerere) were shut down on Monday while non-teaching staff engaged in a strike due to budget issues. Police forces were deployed.

Strike:At least 6 universities (Mbarara, Kyambogo, Busitema, Gulu, Muni (Arua) and Makerere) were shut down on Monday while non-teaching staff engaged in a strike due to budget issues. Police forces were deployed.
Student rioters damaged Mbarara central police station and were later arrested.
Arua nursing students demonstrated to denounce poor management of examinations. They stoned the laboratory building. 13 students were later suspended.
Residents of Gulu demonstrated against the local MP.
Police officers arrest four demonstrators at an illegal protest.

assoc_actor_1: NRM Poor Youth Forum: National Resistance Movement Poor Youth Forum
notes: Poor Youth NRM protested in front of the US Embassy in Kampala to denounce alleged arrests of some of their members. Police officers stopped the protest.
Due to an alleged theft, students stormed a dormitory. 2 students were injured during the riot while 13 arrested were later arrested and 120 suspended.
Following the death of an Alur fishermen few days ago, clashes occurred between Alur and Bagungu in Hoima. One person was killed and three others injured. Police was also deployed.
Protests erupted in Kabale Referral Hospital due to lack of security and violence against health agents. Police has been deployed to strengthen the security.
Re-election of a former Imam, who had previously fired for being unqualified for the position, caused protests during Eid day in Soroti.
Clash between Alur and Bagungu led to one death, an Alur fishermen in Hoima. His wife was also injured.
Hundreds protest after Ethiopian Arline suspended its flights.
South Sudanese politician Peter Abdulrahman Sule abducted in Adjumani in July.
Students protests turned into riots when students started storming schools offices. Police forces intervened, using tear gas to disperse the crowd, arresting five.
Several groups of protesters gathered In Mbale after Mbabazis arrest earlier in the day. Police forces had to disperse them, and several protesters were arrested.
Ugandan and Kenyan Pokots attempted to grabs animals under protection of UPDF soldiers. Clashes occurred leading to two dead among Pokots.
Arrests: Former FDC President Besigye and 2016 presidential hopeful was arrested by Police forces in Kasangati, and released several hours later.

Protesters gathered in front of the police station where Besigye is detained an asked for his released. Police forces had to disperse them using tears gas. Several protesters were arrested including FDCs Iron Lady Ingrid Turinawe.
Arrests: Mbabazi - ex-Prime Minister was arrested in Njeru (on his way to Mbale were he had to attend a meeting). He was released several hours later.
Protests in Mbale prior to the visit of Mbabazi - 2016 presidential hopeful.

actor2: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: Clashes between UPDF and Congolese Militias in Nketo village (Kisoro district) led to one death, UPDF-side. However, Congolese militias were defeated, and retreated to DRC
Kinyara cane cutters protested due to payment issues.
Refusing to stop, a boda boda cyclist was shot down by a police officer.
Nude Nakasongola residents protest about land demarcation issues.
A Besigye supporter is shot by a member of Police Forces during a protest by the opposition in Najjanankumbi. The protester survived the shooting.

Another Muslim cleric - sheikh Ibrahim Hassan Kirya - was shot by unidentified armed men in Bweyogerere near Kampala. Several Muslim clerics have been killed over the last few months in Uganda. Another man was wounded as well during the shooting.

assoc_actor_2: NRM Poor Youth Forum: National Resistance Movement Poor Youth Forum
notes: Seven pro-Mbabazi youth arrested, including NRM Poor youth national coordinator, during a protest. Police forces said the demonstration was non authorized.
NGO Press Freedom Groups offices were raided overnight.
Due to decision to forbid visits from opposite sex friends at the Bishop Barham College, students protested.

Rioters stormed a barrier recently settled at the border with DRC (Vurra Customs Post). They argued the closure of the border is ruining their businesses. Police Forces had to intervene to stop them, using tear gas.
Protesters demonstrated to denounce Kivoora stone quarry closure.
Residents in Bombo and Nyimbwa sub counties protested to denounce pollution from a nearby factory.
Residents in Bombo and Nyimbwa sub counties protested to denounce pollution from a nearby factory.
Protesters demonstrated in Nsasi to denounce poor state of road.
Following the death of man over the previous night (killed by Police Forces), riots erupted in Sembabule, near the Town Council.
Women protested over a land dispute over the Soroti Universitys land. Police fired bullets in the air to disperse mob.
A mob attempted to lynch a suspected thief. A policeman intervened - killing 1 and wounding three others.
Kigezi Tea Workers demonstrated in Kabale from their workplace to the Central Police Station. They protested over pay.

Riots erupted on Thursday in Pader town. Police has to disperse the crowd using tears gas and rubber bullets. Riot's motives were the death of Ronald Odon, which occurred in police cell, where he was detained for traffic offense.
Police are suspected of having arrested 5 alleged thieves, holding them in jail without feeding them over three days.
After the arrest of UNATUs Chairperson, hundreds of teachers stormed the police station.
Muslim leader was shot down.
Students demonstrated at Uganda Christian University to denounce difficulties to access campus, high tuition and long lectures. Police was deployed to stop the strike.
Peaceful demonstration over land protest, turned into a riot. The rioters attempt to lynch two Chinese investors who manage to flee the site unharmed.

Movement of forces: Police deployed around home of former FDC leader Kizza Besigye in Kasangati, to block him from attending Parliament session about constitutional amendment bill. Also stopped mayor of Kampala

A land dispute leads to 2 fatalities when two people are lynched for cultivating disputed land. The event involved factions belonging to families of Haji Malaiki Koire and Hajji Fadhi. Police arrested 40 people, suspected to be involved in clashes.
Disagreement between residents and Chinese Road contractor over destruction of graves led to clashes. Resident District Commissioner mediated the situation.
Alur cultivators destroyed a fence, separating them from cattle keepers.
Kabale Health Workers protest against unexplained salary reductions.
Opposition supporters protest in Gulu town to denounce campaign posters of NRM ruling party.

assoc_actor_1: NRM Poor Youth Forum: National Resistance Movement Poor Youth Forum
notes: Peaceful demonstration of NRM Poor Youth in front of the home of ex-Ugan Prime Minister Amama Mbabazi to call him standing for the next presidency.

Residents in Bukedea clash with police during a protest against the grabbing of their land by a Chinese engineering company. The police fired in the air to disperse the demonstrators who retaliate with stones.
Teachers protest suspicious deductions and delayed payment of salaries.
UPDF attacked fishermen in Kalangala; a journalist tried to take photo. He was then attacked by the UPDF.
Due to a land dispute, two clans (Pawaja and Pobira) fought in Wigweng village. Six people were admitted at the hospital.
Due to a land dispute, armed villagers from Apaa Ogali attempted to attack two MPs came to solve the issue between these villagers and an Australian investor. The police had to stop the rioters.
To denounce abuses, and demand better work conditions, workers of Busoga area protested.
Residents of Byafura held a demonstration to protest electricity outages in the town.
Protest by cleaners who stopped working two weeks ago.
Naked protesters in Apaa demonstrate in front of Internal Affairs minister Aronda Nyakirima and Lands minister Daudi Migereko. Ownership of Apaa is currently contested by both Amuru and Adjumani

A group of women strip naked before two government ministers and hundreds of people in Apaa village in Pabbo Sub County in Amuru and protest against a planned demarcation of a disputed boundary between Amuru and Adjumani district
Students at Bukalasa Agricultural College protest against the colleges policy of charging late-registration fees. Police fire live ammo in the air to disperse the rioters.
Students beat a suspected thief to death.
Students protest against poor quality meals and alleged torture by their teachers. The students destroy school property prompting the police to respond.
Students protest against poor quality meals and alleged torture by their teachers. The students destroy school property prompting the police to respond.
An officer attached to the Uganda Peoples Defense Forces has been shot dead by suspected Pian warriors in Nakapiripirit District
A man accused of murdering an associated during a drunken argument is killed by residents.
A resident of Mwizi sub county Rwampara county Mbarara district is killed by angry residents when they found him slaughtering a stolen goat.
UPDF and police violently evict civilians from a contested plot of land, leading to multiple serious injuries.
Makerere University Muslim students stage a peaceful demonstration and demand that police renounces allegations labelled against Muslim theological and Koran schools (Madrasas) as terror cells.

The chief prosecutor probing the 2010 twin bombings that killed 76 people in Kampala is shot dead by an unidentified group. Sources differ over whether the killing was carried out by a militant or primarily criminal group.
A bomb blast injures two inmates of Gulu central prison. The identity of planters is unknown.
13 youths allied to ex-Prime Minister Amama Mbabazi protest outside the US embassy and are arrested by police.
Cultivators and pastoralists clash over land. The cultivators accuse the pastoralists of letting their animals wreck the local agriculture.
Around 15 March 2015 (month of), unexploded ordnance killed two civilians and wounded another at Kamusenene village (Nakaseke district).
Property destruction: Unidentified assailants burn down camps and properties belonging to Salaf Muslims on March 12 and 13.
Police fire teargas at rioting students. The students were demonstrating over the universities policy of 100% payment of tuition within the first six weeks of the semester.
Two suspected cattle thieves are killed by residents
Arrests: 34 suspected ADF rebels are arrested.
Clans in Kitgum clash, leaving 24 homesteads burnt and 24 cows stolen. The violence stemmed from the death of a child.

NRM members occupy the office of Lira Resident District Commissioner, complaining that their names had been erased from a list of beneficiaries of shs 200 million pledged to 65 party loyalists from Lango by Museveni.
National Resistance Movement publicity secretary for Namayingo district, Mr David Tito Okware, is shot dead by unknown assassins.

A group of about 30 men with clubs attack two journalists leaving both of them hospitalised. The journalists had recently published pieces alleging that the Tooro Royal family had been acquiring land illegally. The police reportedly refused to investigate the assault.
Clan militias clash over access to hunting grounds. A resident dies during the clashes.

assoc_actor_2: Banyankole Ethnic Group (Uganda); Banyarwanda Ethnic Group (Uganda)
notes: Indigenous community member kill a pastoralist. The pastoralist was accused of grazing his animals on the cultivators crops.
Journalists march to Naguru police station to protest against the beating of a journalist by a member of the police forces. They are intercepted by police and dispersed with pepper spray.

assoc_actor_1: NAU: National Association of the Unemployed
notes: Activist youth group - National Association of the Unemployed - demonstrates in Kampala .
A journalist covering a demonstration by an activist youth group - National Association of the Unemployed - in Kampala is detained and severely beaten into a coma by the police.
Arrests: Rwandan genocide suspect Jean Paul Birindabagabo is arrested and extridited to the ICC.

Unidentified assailants attack Sheikh Haruna Jjemba. The assailants exchange fire with Jjembas bodyguard before withdrawing. The attack comes in the aftermath of a string of attacks on notable Muslim figures. Official sources blame the ADF while other sources other sources attribute the murders to long-running disputes between rival Muslim factions over property and leadership. No body was killed in the battle.

Arrests: Military police surround the residence of ex-general Sejusa in a bid to arrest him. Sejusa recently returned after going into exile for allegedly revealing that Museveni is organising for his son to succeed him.
Police break into a mosque and evict protesters who occupied the building in a demonstration against the mosque s current clerical leadership.

Looting: Attackers suspected to have come from Amuru District invade the Adjumani area and burn more than 17 houses to ashes and loot 27 animals. The area is contested between residents of the two the communities.

actor1: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
notes: Muslim cleric and Kampala District Amir Sheikh Mustafa Bahiiga, is shot dead in Bwebajja on Entebbe Road. Police identify the ADF as the perpetrators and argue that the killings were carried out in response to the clerics opposition to religious extremism.

actor1: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
notes: Shiite Muslim sect leader Sheikh Abdu Kadir Muwaya, is shot dead in Mayuge District. Police identify the ADF as the perpetrators and argue that the killings were carried out in response to the clerics opposition to religious extremism.

M23 members clash with the Ugandan military when troops try forcibly repatriate members of the rebel group back to the DRC. The battle lead to many M23 members sustaining injuries although no fatalities have been confirmed.
Bakinga youth attack Batwa civilians after a Bakinga woman is allegedly raped and killed by a Batwa

In Kabowa, Kampala, cyclists protested against a colleague detained for failing to pay operational fees. A journalist covering the story was beaten by the cyclists whom they accused of being a police spy. Police intervened after the beating, arresting 3 people..
Bakinga youth attack Batwa civilians after a Bakinga woman is allegedly raped and killed by a Batwa. Two Batwa die during the clashes.

More than 70 houses were burnt and several people injured when Bunyoro Kingdom loyalists attack the inhabitants of Kaseeta Parish, Kabwooya Sub-county in Hoima, over the control of a seven square mile piece of land bordering the proposed refinery area. The inhabitants are reportedly Congolese.

assoc_actor_1: NRM Poor Youth Forum: National Resistance Movement Poor Youth Forum
notes: A group referring to themselves as the NRM Poor Youth Forum block the town centre with burning debris to block a NRM meeting. The group claim solidarity with ousted prime minister Amama Mbabazi. The group are dispersed by the polive with tear-gas.
Students riot and destroy property due to managements decision to increase university fees.

The parents of a child who was killed by a Kampala Capital City Authority vehicle try to bring the infants body into parliament to protest against the KCCA and demand a formal apology. They are physically blocked by police, but there are no reports of injuries.

Students demonstrate against Nkumba university management's decision to block all students who did not register from sitting exams. The students riots, causing damage to university property, before being dispersed by the police.
Police clash with fighting traders and arrest five of the rioters.
A driver is beaten and almost killed by road users after causing two accidents that left four people injured.
Residents protest against the state of the roads in the local municipality.
Students protest over the high number of missing lecturers and cancelled classes at Gulu University.
Hunger-striking students clash with police.
An FDC youth member is critically injured in an acid attack. The identity of the perpetrators is unknown but the attack is suspected to be politically motivated.

Police fire live rounds to disperse striking students. Several students are hit by bullets and injured. The students, from the capitals Makerere University, were calling for graduation fees to be lowered.

Police fire live rounds to disperse striking students. Several students are hit by bullets and injured. The students, from the capitals Makerere University, were calling for graduation fees to be lowered.
A UPDF officer is killed by a group of locals for stealing a motorbike.

assoc_actor_2: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Uganda Wildlife Authority
notes: Unidentified gunmen attack Sisiyi and Kapkwai ranger stations, killing 2 Ugandan Wildlife Authority rangers and 1 UPDF officer. Local police suspect the perpetrators to be a rebel group raiding ranger stations for firearms.

assoc_actor_2: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Uganda Wildlife Authority
notes: Unidentified gunmen attack Sisiyi and Kapkwai ranger stations, killing 2 Ugandan Wildlife Authority rangers and 1 UPDF officer. Local police suspect the perpetrators to be a rebel group raiding ranger stations for firearms.

Police disperse students protesting against the closure of Busitema University with teargas. There are no reported injuries or reported instances of the demonstrators turning violent or destroying property.

actor2: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Uganda Wildlife Authority
notes: Unidentified gunmen attack Kapkwai ranger station. Local police suspect the perpetrators to be a rebel group raiding ranger stations for firearms.

assoc_actor_2: Banyankole Ethnic Group (Uganda); Banyarwanda Ethnic Group (Uganda)
notes: Indigenous community members attack pastoralist communities. Six children and three women were injured.
Students demonstrate against the decision by management to close the university.
Students demonstrate against the decision by management to close the university.
Students demonstrate against the decision by management to close the university.
Two independent MPs taunt the government after police repeatedly obstruct their planned processions in Masaka.

Two people were burnt to death on a disputed piece of land in Hoima that has been leased to McAlester Energy Resources Limited to construct an oil waste management facility. The land has been at the centre of a dispute between locals and businessmen trying to consolidate control of the land.

Agreement: South Sudanese authorities in Kajo Keji have released 69 Ugandans who were detained following the visit of the disputed Wano village by Inspector General of Police of Uganda Kale Kayihura and his counterpart from South Sudan.
Security measures: Armed forces raided the home of recently sacked PM Amama Mbabazi and disarmed his guards.
Two civilians, one Ugandan and one South Sudanese national, are hacked to death by suspected South Sudanese assailants.At least 10 people were injured and two houses burnt in the attacks.
Traders block off two roads to protest a new energy scheme that has led to power cuts.
South Sudanese youth cross into Moyo and kill five people in retaliation for a previous raid by Ugandans in South Sudanese territory.
Locals march over the detention of local officials in South Sudan. The demonstrators loot South Sudanese owned properties and burn a church.
Two Ugandans residents were injured by suspected South Sudanese. Several livestock and property were also looted in the attack suspected to be in revenge over earlier attacks on South Sudanese.

actor1: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
notes: The SPLA-In Opposition has set up an office in Uganda to coordinate diplomatic and humanitarian tasks.

A local Ugandan chairman and his team is kidnapped by South Sudanese authorities after going to the Moyo area to conduct a census on the disputed district. The Ugandans are then moved to South Sudan where they are interrogated, tortured and detained.
Arrests: Police arrested Al-Shabaab suspects operating in Kampala. The police believe that the suspects were plotting a terrorist attack in Kampala.
Weapons Seizure: The police seize a vehicle reportedly loaded with powerful explosives.

assoc_actor_1: Bushenyi Taxi Drivers and Owners Cooperative Society
notes: Taxi drivers in Bushenyi District block the Mbarara-Kasese highway, protesting the awarding of a park tender to their rival organisation
Artists and actors staged a peaceful demonstration at the National Theatre to protest the courts decision to stop police from arresting film pirates.
The SPLA is suspected of taking hostage several local leaders and journalists in Wano Village, Moyo district during a national census exercise .
Two elderly women are injured during running battles between the police and residents of Kidda Village near Masaka Municipality protesting against the constant power outages in the area.

At least 200 families in Rwamutonga village, Bugambe sub-county, Hoima district, are evicted from a piece of land to pave the way for the construction of an oil waste treatment plant. Houses were torched, property destroyed and residents left homeless. Police fired bullets and teargas. Some residents were reported injured.
Agreement: 43 Karamajong warriors, suspected of fleeing the disarmament campaign a decade ago, surrender to the Ugandan military.
Homosexual Ugandans march through Entebbe to celebrate the annulment of Ugandas anti-homosexuality bill.
During a clash, residents beat a journalist covering the event and cause serious injuries.
Armed residents of Butenga storm a police station to lynch a suspect accused of ritual murder. They collide and fight with a group that supports the accused.
Ugandan police arrest 12 youths Monday carrying a coffin 'mourning' their unemployment. The youths belong to the same group who in June sneaked piglets into parliament protesting corruption.
Students overpower teachers and throw stones at them in a demonstration against corporal punishment.

actor1: Mutiny of Police Forces of Uganda (1986-)
notes: Students under the UNSA umbrella protest against the current form of the students' loan scheme and the non-uniform grading system in higher institutions of learning. 20 are arrested for unlawful assembly
Hundreds of residents of Idudi Town in Iganga District on Wednesday blocked the Iganga-Bugiri highway in protest demanding the transfer of the officer-in-charge of Idudi Police Station.
Ugandan Muslims stage a peaceful demonstration in protest of the current bombardment of Gaza.
Students riot and cause extensive damage to their school after a student is shot and killed by a security guard.
On 23 July 2014, a village headman is hacked to death by an unknown assailant during a village meeting on local security. The assailand accused the headman of practicing witchcraft.

At least 20 houses were burnt following clashes between the immigrant Bahuma cattle keepers and Alur farmers in Kigorobya sub-county, Hoima District [western Uganda]; the two communities also fought with clubs and injured animals
34 bodies are discovered in mass graves in Bundibugo and Western province. The victims are reported to be Bakonzo killed in reprisal attacks.
Agreement: 255 attackers involved in the attacks in early July have surrendered and asked for amnesty. However very few have handed in weapons.
34 bodies are discovered in mass graves in Bundibugo and Western province. The victims are reported to be Bakonzo killed in reprisal attacks.
Local-level members of Uganda's counter-intelligence agency hack to death 7 Bakonzo civilians. The murders happen in the aftermath of an attack by a Bakonzo militia on state forces.
Police round up local Bakonzo residents in response to the recent killings by Bakonzo militias. Numerous civilians are assaulted and beaten during the security sweep.
Police round up local Bakonzo residents in response to the recent killings by Bakonzo militias. Numerous civilians are assaulted and beaten during the security sweep.
On or around 5 July 2014, Bakonzo civilians are targeted by local police and vigilante militias in the aftermath of an attack by Bakonzo militias on state forces. No mention of fatalities.

Ugandan troops killed dozens of tribal gunmen, reportedly Bakonzo, who attacked military and police positions in Bundibuguyo near the DRC border. The fatalities consist of four policemen, three soldiers and three civilians and over 60 attackers.

Gunmen, suspected to be Bakonzo, attacked Bigando village in Kitswamba sub-county in Kasese. At least 10 people were later confirmed killed, including a UPDF soldier and his three children. Most of the dead were Basongora.
The army announced that it had killed a person suspected of involvement in an attack by Muslims on a church in the DRC border region 2 weeks ago, during which a woman was decapitated.
Karugutu Town in Ntoroko District was reportedly attacked in continuing violence in Western Uganda; no fatalities were reported
Gunmen attacked Ntoroko police station. Seven are killed: two soldiers, one civilian and four attackers
Bakonso attack state forces in Kasese. 13 people were killed: one policeman, one soldier and 11 civilians.
Three suspects in a previous attack on a church were attacked by villagers who chased them into the Ibambaro forest; they later died in hospital
Unknown gunmen attacked a church in Kyegegwa District and killed a worshipper before retreating to a mosque where they exchanged fire with police leaving one policeman dead
Muslims reportedly attacked a church in the DRC border region, during which a woman was decapitated and her head placed on the altar.

Two anti-corruption protesters released piglets into the countries parliament in a protest against corruption; the animals were painted in the colours of the ruling party president and had slogans written on them; the men have since been arrested
A boy was killed by police shooting, as police tried to quell riotous pupils during the Inter-schools athletics competitions at Bugembe

Businesses in Tororo town were forced to close amid volleys of gunfire and clouds of tear gas, as police fought running battles with boda boda cyclists protesting the decision by traffic police officers to impound about 300 motorcycles for lack of third party insurance and driving permits; the four-hour scuffle led to the arrest of two security personnel, including a police officer attached to the integrated highway patrol, over illegal shooting and injuring of civilians. A 13 year old boy was killed by a police bullet
Ugandan police dispersed hundreds of people protesting in Fort Portal against President Yoweri Museveni for calling their 22-year-old king a 'child'; about 70 people were arrested
Police clash in a gun battle with armed Balalo cattle herders. The police intervened when the Balalo attacked local residents who had impounded their cows for destroying crops.
The Balalo attack local residents who had impounded their cows for destroying crops.
A journalist alleges that he was badly beaten multiple times by policemen as he was covering local elections
1,295 M23 rebels in Uganda signed amnesty papers vowing to end fighting
Protest at funeral of former chairman of parliaments Budget committee; protest against Fox Odoi, who has spearheaded the fight against the Anti-Homosexuality Act.
A woman was beaten by an unidentified group for being homosexual.
After a fight over a woman, a solider went into a bar and shot 10 people (soldiers and civilians) dead. Then, he killed himself.

Police allow opposition rally in Arua, where former Forum for Democratic Change party president Kizza Besigye and other oppositions leaders peacefully launched their drive for free-and-fair-election campaign at Arua Hill Grounds.

actor1: Military Forces of the United States (2009-2017)
notes: Movement of forces: 150 US soldiers arrived in Uganda to assist in combatting the LRA.

South Sudanese Nuer students in Kampala protested and threatened MPs from Jonglei State, South Sudan. The MPs were delivering a message from Salva Kiir for Nuer diaspora and refugees to not join the SPLA-In Opposition. The MPs left since the students expressed anger but before rioting took place.
Soldiers raided/assaulted civilians on the Luweero campus of Kampala University.
A journalist was beaten up by a mob in Buziranjovu after attempting to delve into a land dispute in the area. Police joined the mob in the assault.

actor1: Military Forces of the United States (2009-2017)
notes: Movement of forces: US sent troops to Uganda to assist with capturing Kony.
Police and Military fired teargas and bullets to disperse rioters/crowds that gathered after a group of opposition leaders were blocked from holding a rally.
A group of three men were attacked for being homosexual. All were admitted to the hospital.
Tensions between South Sudan refugees and host community have escalated. An assault on one refugee took place over scarce resources.
A woman was 'paraded' before local media, outed as a transsexual, beaten, undressed and arrested' by police forces.

actor2: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Presidential Security Unit
notes: A member of the Presidential Guard grabbed a soldiers gun and shot him several times. Other soldiers of the Presidential Guard responded by shooting the initial shooter. Both men died.
Security measures: Police instituted a curfew in response to killings in Lowero the month of February.

An Anti-Gay Bill and Anti-Pornagraphy Act has encouraged attacks against women and banned mini-skirts. In response, women protesters demonstrated against the Act and attacks. Riot police tried to stop the march.
After a tabloid released the names of 200 homosexual individuals, one person on the list was killed.
Three university were raped then killed in the month of February after the passing of the Anti-Pornography Act
Students at Kyambogo University blocked the Chancellor fromentering the campus. Police fired teargas at the students.

Since the passing of the Anti-Pornography Act, women have been stripped in the streets and incidents of sexual violence increased; police have forced women to uncloth in pubic if wearing a inappropriate clothing. 'These women and girls who are citizens of Uganda have been stripped naked by gangs of men on the pretext that they are indecently dressed. '
On 17 February 2014, two people were shot in Luwero, it is suspected the gunmen were after a witch doctor.
A man was killed in 'Kiwogozi zone in Luweero and was reportedly behind a group called B-13, known for terrorising residents at night. '
Unidentified armed group shot and killed a police officer in Kampala in Kajjansi town .
Unidentified armed group fought with police. 1 police officer died and 2 of the armed group died. The shooting took place in Kampala in Nalumunye near the Jomayi Estates .
Police sexually and physically assaulted a transgender man, also paraded him before the media
A letter bomb was sent to Parliament Speaker Rebecca Kadaga. Her aide opened the letter bomb and was hospitalised.
The Kibiniko militia attacked foreigners surveying the wetlands.
Community mob in Asinge killed a man who was suspected to have robbed and raped his neighbor.

Clashes between South Sudanese refugees in Elegu camp in Amuru District and those in Nzaipi in Adjumani District. 'clashes in Elegu cropped up after three men from the Nuer tribe stabbed a man who is believed to be from the Dinka tribe with a knife after a bitter exchange.' Police say incidents occur daily.

3 people ended up dead after a police man shot a man suspeted of stealing a phone. After police shot the man, two other men went after the officers. Police who shot the civilians are under investigation.
Security Measures: Uganda closes border with South Sudan and increases troop presence.
Police stop, arrest, beat and torture a journalist for the Associated Press.
Kampalas city mayor, an opponent of the President, was dismissed from office sparking protests. Protesters opposed the decision and pelted police with stones. Police fired teargas into the crowds.
Report refers to land problems between communities and police clashing with angry residents for land rights but is not specific.
Students protested the lack of teaching staff at Kyambogo University. Police intervened and fired teargas at the protesters.
Agreement: Makenga, leader of M23, and several hundred M23 fighters, surrendered to Uganda military at Mgahinga National Park.
Students demonstrated for better facilities and timely release of grades.

actor2: Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
notes: Agreement: M23 re-entered Uganda to resume peace talks.

actor2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
notes: DRC Military fired on the town of Maziba from an aircraft while trying to suppress M23. 4 Ugandans were killed.
Police fired teargas at student demonstrators who wre contaminating food with soap and urine to protest an increase in meal fees.
A farmer was killed by an unknown group
A man was shot by private security forces. The man who was shot was suspected to be a thief.

Recruitment: Security chiefs in Sembabule are concerned that M23 is recruiting in the district. In addition, it was reported that people are being trafficked from Budaka, Kibuku, and Pallisa. Police have rescued Busoga children from being sent into the conflict.
A mob attacked casual laborers in Mubende, injuring 2 people. The riots were over land.
In a second wave of riots over land, an armed mob attacked laborers. Police intervened and arrested 35 people.
Police fought with armed robbers who had AK 47s. 1 person was arrested.
Armed gunmen robbed two NGO workers.
A robbery at a store in Kakindo left two people dead.
2 Cattle traders were shot on their way back from the market by robbers on the Kyankwanzi-Hoima highway.
Security guards for Saracen Ltd. rioted for better salaries. Police intervened.

South Sudanese stormed the police station in Olego, near Atiak, to demand the release of a Ugandan who hit a South Sudanese girl. Two South Sudanese were arrested. Reportedly, one South Sudanese was SPLA and holding a gun for intimidation.
Security Measures: After the Kenya Attacks, Uganda increased security.
